[[es:Brief]]

'''Edward Manuel Fram''' (1905–1955) was a Christian Iraqi businessman, merchant and philanthropist.
[[File:Edward M Fram.jpg|thumb|right|Edward Fram]]
==Business activities==
===Insurance=== Living and working in [[Basra]] in what was then the [[Kingdom of Iraq]], Edward Fram was a key figure in the country's [[Insurance in Iraq|modern insurance industry]], as the owner of one of Iraq's first [[insurance]] agencies operating under the Insurance Companies Act No. 74 (1 April 1936). This was the first Iraqi law passed to specifically regulate the industry.<ref name="almosul1">{{cite web|url=http://www.almosul.com/Heritage/History/IraqHistory/Begining_of_Insurance_Iraq.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Beginnings of Insurance and Regulation of Insurance Activity in Iraq - An Overview |author=Misbah Kamal |website=Almosul.com |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> Prior to this, only 3 insurance companies were known to be operating in Iraq, under the Ottoman Commercial Law of 9 August 1904,<ref name="almosul1"/><ref>Hanna Batatu, The Old Social Classes and New Revolutionary Movements of Iraq, (London, al-Saqi Books, 2000)</ref> one of which was the General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corporation (now Aviva Insurance Ltd.) from 1928.<ref name="aviva">{{cite web|url=http://heritage.aviva.com/our-history/companies/a/aviva-insurance-ltd/|publisher=heritage.aviva.com|title=Aviva Insurance Ltd - Heritage - Aviva plc|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref> By the time of the nationalisation of the industry in 1964, there were still just 15 branches and agencies of regional (Arab) and foreign insurance companies across Iraq, including Egypt's Al-Chark Insurance Company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iraqshistory.blogspot.co.uk/2008/08/insurance-in-iraq-in-arabic-english.html |title=History of IRAQ: Insurance in IRAQ - in Arabic & English |website=Iraqshistory.blogspot.co.uk |date=2008-08-29 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> Al-Chark (part of Misr Insurance since 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=http://misrholding.co/Data/HTMLEditor/Doc/Misr%20Asset%20Management%20Company%20profile.pdf |format=PDF |title=Misr Holding : Company Profile |website=Misrholding.co |accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref>) was the first to set up an agency in [[Emirate of Transjordan|Transjordan]] towards the end of the 1940s and was one of the first in Iraq, where Edward Fram acted as their agent from as early as 1936.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dNK9UZI7oscC&printsec=frontcover&dq=inauthor:%22Peter+Borscheid%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGvr_MuOzJAhVFvBQKHVUhBJgQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=World Insurance|website=Books.google.co.uk|editor=Peter Borscheid|accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref><ref name="misbahkamal">{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/3778468/Insurance_Agencies_in_Iraq_1936|title=Insurance Agencies in Iraq 1936|author=Misbah Kamal|website=Academia.edu|accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref> Fram also represented France's oldest insurer L’Union de Paris (later UAP, now part of AXA) and other insurance companies, along with [[Shafiq Ades]], [[Andrew Weir, 1st Baron Inverforth]] and other notable businessmen.<ref name="misbahkamal"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://02e37fc.netsolhost.com/site/Commercial%20Directory%20of%20Iraq.pdf |format=PDF |title=Commercial Directory of Iraq |website=02e37c.netsolhost.com |accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref>[[File:L'union de Paris insurance company, Baghdad Branch.jpg|thumb|right|Agents and representatives of L'Union de Paris, Baghdad Branch. Edward Fram (top right), Clement Shammas (top left). In 1966, Shammas was appointed by Iraq’s then Prime Minister [[Abdul Rahman al-Bazzaz]] as the head of the Iraqi Insurance Organisation (abolished in 1988). Taken by A.Abbosh & Co., photographer who held the Royal Warrant to H.M. the King of Iraq; date unknown.]]
===Bonds and securities=== Fram was one of the first and main players in Basra's nascent [[Bond (finance)|bonds]] and securities markets from the mid-1930s.<ref name="auto">The Iraq Directory 1936, p. 139, p. 150, p. 152 and p. 194 (published by Dangoor Printing House under the supervision of the Iraqi Ministry of the Interior)</ref> His name is the only one listed in the Basra bonds section within Iraq's sole pre-Baathist business directory, published by the Interior Ministry in 1936.<ref name="auto"/>
===Other=== Fram was a major goods importer, exporter, makers' representative and also acted as the exclusive agent in Iraq for [[Selfridges]], amongst other western companies. During the Second World War, he provided housing for British troops as part of the development of Basra as a "large-scale base"<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=The Grand Alliance|author=Churchill, W.|date=1986|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|isbn=9780395410578|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zVdux2KfenoC&pg=PA404|page=404|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref>http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/UN/UK/LondonGazette/37685.pdf</ref> and traded scrap metal left by the British military after the war, as did other well-known merchants such as Naji Al-Khedhairi.<ref name="iraqijews">{{cite web|url=http://www.iraqijews.org/commlead.html|publisher=iraqijews.org|title=Community Leaders|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref> Fram also ran the Basra office of [[Iraq Tours]], the country's first travel agency, which had Iraqi Prime Minister [[Tawfiq al-Suwaydi]] as chairman, and which played a key role in [[Operation Ezra and Nehemiah]] alongside the Near East Transport Company and the Israeli national airline El Al.<ref name="dailycaller">{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2016/06/03/when-iraq-expelled-its-jews-to-israel-the-inside-story/|publisher=dailycaller.com|title=When Iraq Expelled Its Jews To Israel: The Inside Story | The Daily Caller|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=The Jewish Exodus from Iraq, 1948-1951|author=Gat, M.|date=2013|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9781135246549|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B_r3_-9ZU1YC&pg=PA97|page=97|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=The Making of Modern Israel: 1948-1967|author=Stein, L.|date=2013|publisher=Wiley|isbn=9780745636238|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nWkYAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT23|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref>
==Death== Edward Fram died aged 50 in a car accident, a short distance from his hometown of Basra, on his return from a visit to the [[Hanna-Sheikh]] family's [[Abu Al-Khaseeb]] retreat. A member of the Al-Sa'adoon family with whom he was travelling also died in the crash, along with the chauffeur.
==Family and legacy== Edward Fram was survived by seven children (five daughters, two sons) and his wife, Selima (1920–1961). His youngest daughter, Thelma Edward Marougy (née Fram), is a fluid specialist at [[Eaton Corporation]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF01393562 |title=The X-ray crystal structure of two osmium(VI) catecholato complexes, Os(O2C6H4)3 and Os[O2C6H2(Bu-t)2]3 |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29 |doi=10.1007/BF01393562 |volume=3 |pages=255–256 |journal=Transition Metal Chemistry|year=1978 |last1=Hursthouse |first1=Michael B. |last2=Fram |first2=Thelma |last3=New |first3=Lucy |last4=Griffith |first4=William P. |last5=Nielson |first5=Alastair J. }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfpa.com/tech_papers/2000/i00-9_12.pdf |format=PDF |title=Technical Paper Series : Fluid Viscosity Selection Criteria for Hydraulic Pumps and Motors |author=Paul W. Michael |website=Nfpa.com |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kerns |first=Jeff |url=http://machinedesign.com/hydraulics/making-move-eco-friendly-hydraulic-fluids |title=Making the Move to Eco-friendly Hydraulic Fluids | Hydraulics content from |publisher=Machine Design |date=2013-08-07 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eaton.com/ecm/groups/public/@pub/@eaton/@hyd/documents/content/ct_172164.pdf |format=PDF |title=Fluid Power Journal |website=Eaton.com |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Edward Fram is the grandfather of American technology executive and namesake, [[Edward Y Abbo]] - formerly Senior Vice President at [[Oracle Corporation]] and currently President and Chief Technical Officer at C3 IoT,<ref name="c3iot">{{cite web|url=http://c3iot.com/about/leadership/#executive-team|publisher=c3iot.com|title=Leadership - C3 IoT|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref> a data analytics company founded in 2009 by [[Thomas Siebel|Tom Siebel]]. He is also the grandfather of Michael Y Abbo, an emergency physician and assistant clinical professor at the [[University of California San Francisco]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esem2014.com/dr-michael-abbo/ |title=Dr.Michael Abbo |website=ESEM2014.com |date=2015-01-27 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Ayad Sarraf, former manager of [[Fulham Deaf FC]] and now club secretary,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hearingtimes.co.uk/Video/1087/Fulham%20Deaf%20FC%20win%20cup%20final |title=Fulham Deaf FC win cup final |website=Hearingtimes.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/may/07/fulham-deaf-fc |title=Fulham Deaf FC Win Cup | Fulham Football Club |website=Fulhamfc.com |date=2013-05-07 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Luisa Toffolatti, an Italian oncologist and researcher based in Treviso <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Luisa_Toffolatti/citations |title=Luisa Toffolatti - Citations |website=Researchgate.net |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> and Sally Fram, PhD - a British cancer expert and regulatory affairs executive at [[AstraZeneca]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Sally-Fram/1965821195 |title=Sally Fram | AstraZeneca PLC |website=ZoomInfo.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |date=2011 |doi=10.1007/978-1-61779-207-6_3 |chapter=HGF-Induced DU145 Cell Scatter Assay |title=Cell Migration |volume=769 |pages=31 |series=Methods in Molecular Biology |last1=Fram |first1=Sally T. |last2=Wells |first2=Claire M. |last3=Jones |first3=Gareth E. |editor-first=Claire M. |editor-last=Wells |editor-first2=Maddy |editor-last2=Parsons |isbn=978-1-61779-206-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00018-013-1528-5#page-1 |title=A PAK6–IQGAP1 complex promotes disassembly of cell–cell adhesions |date=2013-12-19 |accessdate=2015-12-29 |doi=10.1007/s00018-013-1528-5 |volume=71 |issue=14 |pages=2759–2773 |journal=Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences|last1=Fram |first1=Sally |last2=King |first2=Helen |last3=Sacks |first3=David B. |last4=Wells |first4=Claire M. |pmid=24352566 |pmc=4059965}}</ref> Edward Fram is the great-grandfather of Rafi Allos, an intellectual property specialist and associate at [[Allen and Overy]].<ref>http://www.allenovery.com/people/en-gb/Pages/Rafi-Allos.aspx</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Felix Haas | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year with {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = Munich, Germany | baptised = <!-- will not display if birth_date is entered --> | disappeared_date = <!-- {{disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates (displays "Burial place" as label) --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = German | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = Technical University of Munich | occupation = | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | agent = <!-- Discouraged in most cases, specifically when promotional, and requiring a reliable source --> | known_for = | notable_works = <!-- produces label "Notable work"; may be overridden by |credits=, which produces label "Notable credit(s)"; or by |works=, which produces label "Works" --> | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | weight = <!-- "X kg", "X lb" or "X st Y lb" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source; do not add a religious denomination here --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = <!-- may be used (optionally with mother parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Felix Haas''' is a [[Germans|German]] [[entrepreneur]] and [[investor]] based in [[Munich]]. He is most known for founding [[Amiando]] and IDnow.<ref name=ALL/> He is also the co-organizer and host of [[Bits & Pretzels]], Germany’s largest founders' event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starting-up.de/geld/investoren/business-angels-praesentieren-sich-folge-1.html|title= Im Porträt: Business Angel Felix Haas|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
Haas founded his first company, TiberiumSun Networks, in 1997, while still in high school. After completing his education and spending two years in [[Silicon_Valley|Silicon Valley]], he co-founded [[Amiando|Amiando]] in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dld-conference.com/users/felix-haas|title=Felix Haas|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> The company was acquired by [[XING]] in 2010 and Haas co-founded IDnow in 2013. He is an active business angel investor. He has invested in over 50 internet startups in Germany and serves on the board of several companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informilo.com/2015/06/germanys-crazy-gang-the-first-wave-of-entrepreneurs/|title= Germany’s Crazy Gang: The First Wave Of Entrepreneurs|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
== Education and early career == Haas was born and raised in Munich, Germany. While he was in high school, he actively attended computer and technology fairs. At a computer fair in Munich, he had the idea to develop a global content platform focused on computer games, movie and music. After working several weeks on designing the website, he launched tiberiumsun.com and founded TiberiumSun Entertainment in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tiberiumweb.org/history.php|title= Site History|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> Haas completed his high school in 2000 and joined [[Technical University of Munich]] for B.Sc. in Electrical Engineering and Information Technology.<ref name=ALL>{{cite web|url=http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/idnow-haas-amiando|title=Das ist das neue Startup der Amiando-Gründer|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
While studying at Technical University of Munich, Haas joined [[BMW]] as an intern and worked with the company in Munich and the USA. After completing his B.Sc., he enrolled for M.Sc. at Technical University of Munich and received his degree in 2006. During his MS.c., he also worked as a project supervisor on a collaborative project between BMW and [[Stanford University]] in [[Palo Alto]]. He was working on the BMW team that created [[Google Maps]] "Send to Car" and he co-authored the patent describing the link between internet mapping services like Google Maps and automobiles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nextconf.eu/person/felix-haas/ |title=Felix Haas|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
== Career == In 2006, Haas founded Felix Haas Investments to invest in start ups in Germany. Later in 2006, he co-founded Amiando, an online platform for event registration and ticketing.<ref name=TA/> The company became very successful over the ensuing years and powered most of Europe’s technology events including LeWeb, DLD or Online Marketing Rockstars. Amiando received wide recognition for its innovative approach in event ticketing as well for its innovative business model. In 2010, Amiando was awarded Global Technology Pioneer status by the [[World Economic Forum]]. It was later sold to [[XING]] the same year.<ref name=TA>{{cite web|title =Amiando Co-Founder Marc Bernegger: Key Insights as a Serial Internet Entrepreneur | url =https://www.techinasia.com/amiando-marc-bernegger | accessdate =20 January 2016}}</ref>
Haas left the position of CEO after the acquisition of Amiando and began focusing on investing in startups. In later 2012, he became a founding investor [[Kreditech]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kreditech.com/what-we-do/|title=What We Do|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> a big data infrastructure that allows for credit bureau independent acquisition, identification, scoring and retention management in consumer lending. The next year, together with his former Amiando co-founders, he co-founded IDnow,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/idnow-neues-ident-verfahren-esign |title=Münchner IDnow lässt Verträge per Smartphone unterschreiben}}</ref> the first online solution for convenient and secure online identification of government IDs in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/06/18/idnow-scans-holograms-in-id-cards-to-verify-your-identity-online/ |title= IDnow Scans Holograms In ID Cards To Verify Your Identity Online |accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
Since January 2015, Haas co-organizes and hosts Bits & Pretzels, a three-day founders' event, during Munich's Oktoberfest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gruender.wiwo.de/bits-pretzels-endlich-muss-ich-muenchner-nicht-mehr-in-berlin-treffen/2/ |title= Bits & Pretzels Endlich Muss Ich Muenchner Nicht Mehr In Berlin Treffen|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> Through Felix Haas Investments, he has invested in over 50 internet startups including JustBook,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theheureka.com/justbook-funding-round|title= Exclusive: Amiando's Felix Haas and DailyDeal's Heilemann Brothers Invest Six-Digit-Figure in JustBook|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> Iwoca,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/felix-haas-iwoca-brille24-point-nine-capital-honey-netto-deliveroo|title= Felix Haas investiert in Iwoca – und weitere News|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> Whow Games, Jodel and Kaeuferportal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.noah-conference.com/company/felix-haas-investments/ |title=Felix Haas Investments|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> He is frequently invited to speak at Internet conferences and universities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deutsche-startups.de/2015/08/27/angel-investing-ist-ein-bisschen-wie-poker-spielen/ |title=Angel Investing ist ein bisschen wie Poker spielen|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
=== Not-for-Profit activities === In 2013, he was appointed as an advisor to the German Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology. In this role, he has been an advisor to the German Vice Chancellor and Minister, [[Sigmar Gabriel]] and a Member of official Advisory Group "Young Digital Economy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theheureka.com/philipp-roesler-silicon-valley-jan-2013 |title= Germany's Economics Minister Makes Lightning Visit to Silicon Valley |accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> He also served on the board of Venturate, a platform for early-stage seed-financing for startups.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.venturate.com/startups |title=Gründe für Start-ups über Venturate Crowdfunding zu betreiben|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}

revision.text:
'''Günter Herlitz''' (February 9, 1913 – September 11, 2010<ref>Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, September 14th, 2010</ref>) was born in [[Berlin]] as the son of [[:de:Carl Herlitz|Carl Herlitz]], founder of the [[Herlitz|Herlitz stationery company]].
==Biography== Following the founding of the company by his father in 1904, Günter Herlitz took over the business in 1935. He expanded the company from Berlin into [[Province of Brandenburg|Mark Brandenburg]] and already counted six employees to help with the business. When he was conscripted for military service during the Second World War, Günter Herlitz’s mother took on the running of the business.
During the Second World War, the business premises were destroyed by bombs several times, and thus Günter Herlitz resumed business operations in 1945, following completion of his military service, in a basement in the Berlin district of [[Moabit]]. Initially selling bargains of all kinds, the Herlitz company was the only one of around 20 Berlin wholesalers to succeed in securing a minimal amount of goods during the [[Berlin Blockade]]. When the blockade ended, the company extended its product range considerably. As one of the most important wholesale firms nationwide, Herlitz was able to employ 50 people by 1950.
Due to the political situation in Germany at the time, it became increasingly difficult for the company to get its goods from West Germany to Berlin. As a result, Günter Herlitz decided to manufacture his own stationery. The company began with the production of exercise books, drawing pads and index cards. In 1955, the company was already processing 60 tons of paper each month. Even though the political situation at the time initially prevented Herlitz from supplying customers outside [[West Berlin]], the company was able to boast an annual turnover circa 1.1 million Euro.
Initial attempts to sell the products on the West German market were unsuccessful; however, in 1960, the breakthrough came about with notebooks and drawing pads with illustrated covers, which was an absolute novelty at the time.<ref>Der Tagessiegel, October 27th, 1960</ref> In the following years, from 1960 to 1994, the company was able to double its turnover each year. This meant an increase in annual turnover from 2 million Euros in 1960 to 885 million Euros in 1994.
In 1996, Günter Herlitz was honoured for his life’s work at the company’s general meeting and resigned from the board of management. He became the company’s honorary chairman. From then on, he never attended another general meeting of the company.
To this day, the company headquarters are located in Berlin.
After the death of Günter Herlitz in September 2010, his family continues his social commitment and is amongst the most active families in Berlin. In 2003 his son, [[Klaus and Eva Herlitz|Dr Klaus Herlitz]] and his wife founded the [[Buddy Bear Help]] children's charities organization.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.herlitz.de/en.html Official Website of Herlitz AG]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Herlitz, Gunter}} [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Berlin]] [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Officers Crosses of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]]

page.title: Index of articles related to terms of service and privacy policies

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} This is a list of articles about [[terms of service]] and [[privacy policies]]. These are also called terms of use, and are rules one must agree to, in order to use a service. The articles fall in two main categories: descriptions of terms used for specific companies or products, and descriptions of different kinds of terms in general. Articles on companies vary widely in the amount of detail they give on terms of service. Annotations show what is available in the article on each company, and need to be updated as those articles are improved.
Terms of service are regularly the subject of news articles throughout the English-language press, such as in the US,<ref name="ny14">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/23/upshot/one-third-of-top-websites-restrict-customers-right-to-sue.html |title=One-Third of Top Websites Restrict Customers' Right to Sue |last=Merrill |first=Jeremy B. |date=23 October 2014 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name="ny17">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/03/technology/uber-greyball-program-evade-authorities.html |title=How Uber Deceives the Authorities Worldwide |last=Isaac |first=Mike |date=3 March 2017 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name="ti12">{{Cite news |url=http://business.time.com/2012/08/28/7-surprising-things-lurking-in-online-terms-of-service-agreements/ |title=7 Surprising Things Lurking in Online 'Terms of Service' Agreements |last=Luckerson |first=Victor |work=Time |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US |issn=0040-781X}}</ref><ref name="wired">{{Cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/story/zoe-quinn-crash-override-book-excerpt/ |title=Book Excerpt: Zoë Quinn on the Problem of Terms of Service |last=Quinn |first=Zoe |date=9 September 2017 |work=WIRED |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref> UK,<ref name="gu17">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/03/terms-of-service-online-contracts-fine-print |title=Click to agree with what? No one reads terms of service, studies confirm |last=Berreby |first=David |date=3 March 2017 |work=the Guardian |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="gu15">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jun/15/i-read-all-the-small-print-on-the-internet |title=I read all the small print on the internet and it made me want to die |last=Hern |first=Alex |date=15 June 2015 |work=The Guardian |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref name="in17">{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/twitter-new-terms-of-service-truth-original-content-tweets-embed-messages-posts-a7929256.html |title=People are terrified about Twitter's new terms of service |last=Griffin |first=Andrew |date=4 September 2017 |work=The Independent |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-GB}}</ref> Africa,<ref name="pu17">{{Cite news |url=http://punchng.com/dealing-with-legal-issues-of-digital-afterlife/ |title=Dealing with legal issues of digital afterlife |last=Okoriekwe |first=Chuks |date=13 July 2017 |work=Punch Newspapers (Nigeria) |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="st17">{{Cite news |url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/sci-tech/2017-09-07-if-youre-on-facebook-instagram-or-twitter-read-the-ts-and-cs/ |title=If you're on Facebook‚ Instagram or Twitter‚ read the Ts and Cs |last=GOVENDER |first=SUTHENTIRA |date=7 September 2017 |work=Sunday Times (South Africa) |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref> India,<ref name="et17">{{Cite news |url=http://brandequity.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/digital/twitters-new-terms-of-service-draw-online-criticism/60374030 |title=Twitter's new terms of service draw online criticism – ET BrandEquity |date=5 September 2017 |work=ET Brand Equity (India) |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en}}</ref> Singapore,<ref name="st16">{{Cite web |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/privacy-watchdog-seeks-clarification-on-whatsapps-new-terms |title=Privacy watchdog seeks clarification on WhatsApp's new terms |last=Leow |first=Annabeth |date=29 August 2016 |website=The Straits Times |language=en |access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref> and Australia.<ref name="smh17">{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/web-culture/teens-finally-understand-rights-after-lawyer-translates-instagram-terms-into-plain-english-20170108-gtny6d.html |title=Teens finally understand rights after lawyer translates Instagram terms into plain English |last=Wang |first=Amy B. |date=9 January 2017 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="smh16">{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/when-you-cant-find-the-fine-print-or-read-it-20160328-gnsqzg.html |title=Never read the terms and conditions? You're not alone |last=Feldman |first=Noah |date=29 March 2016 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref> Terms of service are also addressed in a widely reviewed documentary,<ref name="imdb">{{Cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2084953/externalreviews |title=Terms and Conditions May Apply (2013)-External Reviews |website=IMDB |access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref> academic research,<ref name="fies16">{{Cite paper |last=Fiesler |first=Casey; Cliff Lampe; Amy S. Bruckman |date=2016 |title=Reality and Perception of Copyright Terms of Service for Online Content Creation |url=https://dl.acm.org/ft_gateway.cfm?id=2819931&type=pdf |via=CSCW '16: Proceedings of the 19th ACM Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work & Social Computing,}}</ref><ref name="earp05">{{Cite journal |last=Earp |first=J. B. |last2=Anton |first2=A. I. |last3=Aiman-Smith |first3=L. |last4=Stufflebeam |first4=W. H. |date=May 2005 |title=Examining Internet privacy policies within the context of user privacy values |url=http://www.truststc.org/wise/articles2009/article3.pdf |journal=IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management |volume=52 |issue=2 |pages=227–237 |doi=10.1109/tem.2005.844927 |issn=0018-9391}}</ref><ref name="magi10">{{Cite journal |last=Magi |first=Trina |title=A Content Analysis of Library Vendor Privacy Policies: Do They Meet Our Standards? |url=http://scholarworks.uvm.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1005&context=libfacpub |journal=College & Research Libraries |volume=71 |pages=254–272 |via=University of Vermont}}</ref><ref name="sath17">{{Cite paper |last=Sathyendra |first=Kanthashree Mysore, Shomir Wilson, Florian Schaub, Sebastian Zimmeck, Norman Sadeh |date=7 September 2017 |title=Identifying the Provision of Choices in Privacy Policy Text |url=http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/D17-1293 |journal=Proceedings of the 2017 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing |volume=2017 |pages=2764–2769 |via=Association for Computational Linguistics and Carnegie Mellon University}}</ref> and legal research.<ref name="reid14">{{Cite journal |last=Reidenberg |first=Joel |last2=Travis |first2=Breaux, |last3=Faith |first3=Carnor, Lorrie |last4=Brian |first4=French, |date=2014 |title=Disagreeable Privacy Policies: Mismatches Between Meaning and Users’ Understanding |url=http://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2053&context=btlj |journal=Berkeley Technology Law Journal |language=en |volume=30 |issue=1 |doi=10.15779/z384k33 |issn=1086-3818}}</ref><ref name="Klass17">{{Cite paper |last=Klass |first=Gregory |date=8 September 2017 |title=A Critical Assessment of the Empiricism in the Restatement of Consumer Contract Law |url=http://scholarship.law.georgetown.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3005&context=facpub |via=Georgetown University Law School and SSRN}}</ref>
==Articles which describe specific companies' terms of service==
===Social media=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Privacy concerns with social networking services]] – Partially compares privacy policies, data retention, geo-tagging, data releases *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of Q&A sites]] – Compares topics allowed, copyright, and licensing of user contributions *'''Comparison: '''[[Death and the Internet]] - Compares rules on access after death *[[Facebook#Privacy|Facebook]] Addresses privacy settings and enforcement *[[Instagram#Controversy|Instagram]] Partly addresses commercial re-use of members' posts, and [[Privacy concerns with social networking services#Instagram|geo-tagging]] *[[Pinterest#User data|Pinterest]] Addresses sales of user data and tracking of users on other websites which have a Pinterest button *[[Tencent#Anti-malware software cheating allegations|Tencent]] Partly addresses user security *[[Twitter#Privacy and security|Twitter]] Addresses privacy, data dissemination, security breaches, legal jurisdiction, deletion to comply with national laws and survivors' requests
===Search engines=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Internet privacy#Privacy focused search engines.2Fbrowsers|Privacy-focused search engines/browsers]] – Partially compares location of servers and hiding IP addresses *[[DuckDuckGo#Overview|DuckDuckGo]] Addresses lack of tracking *[[Privacy concerns regarding Google|Google]] Addresses privacy and [[Indemnity#Without negotiations|indemnification]]
===Browsers=== *[[Comodo Dragon#Comodo license and tracking|Comodo Dragon]] Addresses arbitration, tracking, disclosures, liability, and use of the information for advertising *[[Google Chrome#User tracking|Google Chrome]] Addresses tracking of users, and [[Google Chrome#Security|insecurity]] with VPNs *[[Safari (web browser)#License|Safari]] Addresses tracking, disclaimers, and disclosing unique device identifiers "for any purpose"
===Transport=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|Credit card damage waivers]] – Compares credit cards' limits on rental car damages *'''Comparison: '''[[Diminution in value#Car accidents|Diminution in value]] – Compares rental car companies' terms about charging for diminution in value *Air passengers and freight [[Montreal Convention]] 119 states and the EU; [[Warsaw Convention]] 152 states *Road freight: [[CMR Convention]] Europe and Asia; [[Uniform Bill of Lading Act]] USA *Sea freight [[Hague–Visby Rules]] applied in US by the [[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act]]; newer are [[Hamburg Rules]] and [[Rotterdam Rules]] *[[CIV (rail travel)|Trains in Europe (CIV)]] Partly addresses guarantee of arrival and connections, baggage, compensation *Trains in UK [[National Rail Conditions of Travel]] Addresses compensation for delays; links to other issues *[[Indemnity#Without negotiations|Lyft]] Addresses indemnification (user payment of company's legal bills) *[[Contract of carriage#Air travel|Southwest Airlines]] Partly addresses difficulties beyond the airline's control *[[Indemnity#Without negotiations|Uber]] Addresses indemnification (user payment of company's legal bills)
===Credit cards=== *[[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|American Express]] Addresses limits on rental car damages *[[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|Discover]] Addresses limits on rental car damages *[[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|Mastercard]] Addresses limits on rental car damages *[[Visa Inc.#Operating regulations|Visa]] Partly addresses terms imposed on merchants, and [[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|limits]] on rental car damages
===Email=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Death and the Internet]] - Compares rules on access after death
===Utility software=== *[[CCleaner#Licence|CCleaner]] Addresses tracking of users and their software, matching with outside sources of information, use of the information for advertising, data retention, liability *[[GeForce#License|GeForce]] (graphics processing units from Nvidia) Addresses liability, and user data provided to Nvidia, to social media and to advertisers *[[Malwarebytes#License and Privacy|Malwarebytes]] Addresses arbitration, tracking of users and all software they run, their clickstreams, locations, data retention, and use of the information for advertising *[[Microsoft account#History|Microsoft account]] (formerly Passport or Live ID) Partly addresses privacy and allegations of deceptive practices
===Other software=== *'''Comparison: '''[[List of commercial software with available source code]] – Compares copyright, open source, copyright licensing *'''Comparison: '''[[List of commercial video games with available source code]] – Compares copyright licensing
===Online file storage and hosting=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of file hosting services]] - Compares limits on size, bandwidth, expiration *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of online backup services]] - Compares limits on size, bandwidth, server locations, security key management *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of free and open-source software licenses]] *'''Comparison: '''[[Death and the Internet]] - Compares rules on access after death *[[Amazon Drive#Limitations|Amazon Drive]] Addresses file sizes and commercial use *[[Baidu Wangpan#Controversy|Baidu Wangpan]] Partly addresses country of storage *[[Dropbox (service)#Privacy and security concerns|Dropbox]] Partly addresses privacy, ownership of data and deletion *[[Google Drive#Ownership and licensing|Google Drive]] Partly addresses privacy and intellectual property *[[ICloud#Privacy|ICloud]] Partly addresses encryption *[[OneDrive#Privacy concerns|OneDrive]] Partly addresses privacy and usage prohibitions *[[SpiderOak#Main features|SpiderOak]] Partly addresses encryption *[[SecureSafe#Data inheritance|SecureSafe]] Addresses digital inheritance *[[Tresorit#Technology|Tresorit]] Addresses encryption
===Website hosts=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of free blog hosting services]] – Compares limits on size, bandwidth, e-commerce *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of free web hosting services]] – Compares use of ads, archiving, and limits on size, bandwidth, e-commerce, scripting *[[Google Sites#Limitations|Google Sites]] Addresses limits on file sizes, e-commerce, scripting, countries *[[Jimdo#Service|Jimdo]] Addresses limits on e-commerce, languages, location of data storage *[[Tripod.com#Services|Tripod]] Addresses storage, e-commerce, scripting *[[Weebly]] Partly addresses storage, e-commerce *[[Wix.com]] Partly addressed e-commerce *[[WordPress.com]] Partly addresses ads, paid upgrades *[[Yola (webhost)#Features|Yola]] Partly addresses limits on storage, web pages
===Broad comparisons across categories=== *[[Death and the Internet#By website|Death and the Internet]] – Compares terms on retention and access after an account holder dies *[[Indemnity#Without negotiations|Indemnity]] – requirements that users pay companies' legal bills
==Articles which discuss terms of service in general== *[[Acceptable use policy]] *[[Click wrap]] *[[Contract of carriage]] *[[Community standards]] *[[Disclaimer]] *[[Email privacy]] *[[End-user license agreement]] *[[Free license]] *[[Free software license]] *[[Free web hosting service]] *[[Internet privacy]] *[[License compatibility]] *[[Multi-licensing]] *[[Open-source license]] *[[Privacy concerns with social networking services]] *[[Privacy policy]] *[[Proprietary software]] *[[Public domain equivalent license]] *[[Service-level agreement]] *[[Shrink wrap contract]] *[[Site license]] *[[Software license]] *[[Standard form contract]] *[[Terms and Conditions May Apply]] *[[Terms of service]] *[[Terms of Service; Didn't Read]] *[[Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977]]

page.title: International Association for Business and Society

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=September 2014}} {{unreferenced|date=January 2012}} }}
[[File:IABS logo.jpg|thumb|175px|alt=IABS logo]]
The '''International Association for Business and Society''' (IABS) is a [[non-profit organization]] devoted to research and teaching about the relationships between business, government and society. Established in 1990, IABS sponsors a scholarly journal, ''Business and Society'', publishes a newsletter, hosts an annual conference, and publishes an annual conference proceeding. IABS members receive the journal, the newsletter, and the conference proceeding as benefits of membership.
==Publications of the International Association for Business and Society== * ''Business and Society'' ([[Sage Publications]]) * ''International Association for Business and Society Newsletter'', 1992–present * ''[[Proceedings of the International Association for Business and Society]]'', 1990–present
==Annual meetings== Meetings of the International Association for Business and Society Society are held annually in a different location. IABS conferences have been held in the US, Canada, Mexico, Austria, Finland, France, Italy, The Netherlands, and United Kingdom, reflecting the organizations international character.
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.iabs.net/}} * [http://bas.sagepub.com/ ''Business and Society''] * [http://www.iabs.net/Newsletter.aspx ''International Association for Business and Society Newsletter''] * [http://www.pdcnet.org/iabsproc ''Proceedings of the International Association for Business and Society'']
[[Category:Business ethics organizations]] [[Category:Learned societies of the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1990]]
{{philo-org-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Cornelis ("Kees") Bruynzeel''' (February 19, 1900 in [[Rotterdam]] – 1980) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[businessman]], [[timber]] [[merchant]] and [[yachtsman]].
==Early years== Bruynzeel was the son of Cornelis Bruynzeel Sr., who founded a timber factory in 1897, and Antoinette Lels. He studied in [[The Hague]], and took several trips to the United States and Sweden to study progress in automatization and wood manufacturing. In 1920 he became manager of the family's new door factory in [[Zaandam]]. In 1922 he married Titia Verkade, granddaughter of the industrialist [[Ericus Verkade|Ericus Gerhardus Verkade]].
Bruynzeel Jr. was an avid sailor. He won the [[Fastnet race]] for the [[Netherlands]] in 1937 with his [[Sparkman & Stephens|Stephens-designed]] [[yawl]] ''Zeearend'' ("sea eagle", the eagle being the logo of the Bruynzeel company). The Dutch designer [[Piet Zwart]] worked closely with Bruynzeel's father and his brother Willem<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iisg.nl/ondernemers/pdf/pers-0266-02.pdf|title=Biography: Willem Bruynzeel|language=Dutch}}</ref> (he designed their first kitchens) and was involved with the design of the Zeearend as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marcuse.nl/foto.php?pageID=157 |title=Piet Zwart, een veelzijdig avant-gardistisch vormgever |language=Dutch }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Industry Pioneer== In 1939, when the production had expanded to include floors and kitchens and the threat of [[World War II]] was causing a decline in the building industry, he considered alternatives and pioneered the development of new timber materials for the production of the Bruynzeel kitchen<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nai.nl/e/collection/news/2004/0405_bruynzeel_e.html |title=Model by Bruynzeel: Design your own kitchen |publisher=Netherlands Architecture Institute |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060724120633/http://www.nai.nl/e/collection/news/2004/0405_bruynzeel_e.html |archivedate=2006-07-24 |df= }}</ref> and for boat construction. Using a newly developed water-resistant synthetic resin glue, Bruynzeel developed a durable three-ply wood, similar to [[plywood]], for the fabrication of external doors. Bruynzeel went on to extend the concept of the modular kitchen and with [[E.G. van de Stadt]] developed the first industrialised boat construction system in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.valkenklasse.nl/nieuws/newsarch.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050426210812/http://www.valkenklasse.nl/nieuws/newsarch.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-04-26 |title=Valkenklasse |language=Dutch }}</ref>
Today Bruynzeel Multipanel Int. B.V., as it was later renamed, is a leading timber company that specialises in [[Marine (ocean)|marine]] and [[construction]] timber, with distribution throughout [[Europe]], [[North America]] and the [[Caribbean]], amongst others. The Bruynzeel name also lives on as a [[shelf (storage)|shelving]] brand of the Norwegian [[Constructor Group AS|Constructor Group]].
==South Africa== In 1956 Kees Bruynzeel Jr. moved to [[South Africa]], where he owned and operated a company [[Bruply Doors]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icpcredit.com/ReportRequest.asp?sCompanyID=306988|title=Bruply Doors (Pty) Ltd.}}</ref> including a factory at [[Stellenbosch]]. Bruynzeel's South African timber operations now comprise [[PG Bison]] and are controlled by Steinhoff Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steinhoffinternational.com/asp/africa_operations.asp|title=PG Bison and Steinhoff Africa}}</ref>
In 1962, Bruynzeel built a house in [[Stellenbosch]], that was controversial considering the conservative architecture of the time. The roof of the house is shaped like a [[hyperbolic paraboloid]], and is constructed using [[teak]] [[rafter]]s and lined with [[Afrocarpus|yellowwood]]. It was [[design]]ed by [[architect]] [[Aart Bijl]].
==Sailing== Bruynzeel continued sailing and winning races. In the 1937 Fastnet Race "Zeearend" was winner overall. In the Fastnet 1951 Race, "Zeevalk" wasklasse winner and 2. overall. "Stormvogel" was first to finish in the 61 Fastnet, the 62 Buenos Aires-Rio race, the 64 Burmuda race, the Sydney-Hobart, the China Sea, and the 1967 Trans-Pacific Race (Los Angeles-to-Hawaii [[Transpacific Yacht Race|Transpac]] race with the boat ''Stormvogel'' ("Stormbird" or the ''[[Procellariidae|Shearwater]]''), after coming in a close second in 1965.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transpacificyc.org/history/tp03-lists.html |title=The Transpac Race at www.transpacificyc.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060504022510/http://www.transpacificyc.org/history/tp03-lists.html |archivedate=2006-05-04 |df= }}</ref> In 1973, aged 72, Bruynzeel took both line and overall handicap honours in the [[Cape to Rio Yacht Race]] in his boat ''Stormy'';<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rorc.org/admiralscup/history/1957/default.html|title=Excerpt from ''The Admiral's Cup'' by Bob Fisher|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427205526/http://www.rorc.org/admiralscup/history/1957/default.html|archivedate=2006-04-27|df=}}</ref> his progress was followed with keen interest, since he had suffered three [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]]s in the previous year.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://sparkmanstephens.blogspot.nl/2011/05/design-126-zeearend.html Sparkman&Stephens Design 126 - Zeearend] * [http://www.landmarkhouse.com/ Details and photos of the Bruynzeel house] * [http://www.stellenboschwriters.com/bijla.html Aart Bijl, the architect of Bruynzeel house] * [http://www.stellenboschwriters.com/pPages/1.html Photo of SY Stormvogel] * [http://www.bruynzeelmultipanel.com/ Bruynzeel Multipanel Int. B.V. website] * [http://www.steinhoffinternational.com Steinhoff International Limited website] * [http://people.zeelandnet.nl/kooiman70/Hendrik%20Salomons.htm#III.4 C de Haas & Brijnzeel 1870]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Company established by grandparents
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bruynzeel, Kees}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:Dutch male sailors (sport)]] [[Category:People from the Western Cape]] [[Category:People from Rotterdam]]

{{korean name|[[Kim (Korean name)|Kim]]}} {{BLP sources|date=July 2007}} {{Infobox Korean name |hangul={{linktext|김|우|중}} |hanja={{linktext|金|宇|中}} |rr=Gim U-Choong |mr=Kim U-Choong }} '''Kim Woo-Choong''' (born December 19, 1936) was the founder and chairman of the [[Daewoo|Daewoo Group]] (대우). Born in [[Daegu]], he was the son of the provincial governor.
He was a [[paperboy|newspaper delivery boy]] when he was a youngster, helping a family that depended almost solely on him during a brief period. He graduated from the prestigious [[Kyunggi High School]], then finished with an Economics Degree at [[Yonsei University]] in [[Seoul]]. His father was the teacher or mentor of Former President, [[Park Chung Hee]], who in turn supported Kim to a great degree both financially and business-wise.
After graduating from Yonsei, he entered into a small trading corporation, later specialising in textiles and clothing. He broke off and created Daewoo Industries with 5 people as his associates. Using his connections in both alumni of the Yonsei and political backing, he managed to do well, and consecutively bought many different companies. It would not be wrong to say that Daewoo Group was originally built on companies that were bought (most heavily in trouble). Kim was a magician in turning near-bankrupt companies into successive cash machines. With a company that had a history of 30 years, by the 90s, Daewoo Group was listed Number 2 on assets, Number 3 on revenues, an unbelievable achievement for anybody with knowledge of how the other Big 3 Korean companies, ([[Hyundai]], [[LG]], [[Samsung]]), made their mark.
But due to its rather hollow financial structure, even though it had the most Overseas Branch offices, when the [[Asian Financial Crisis]] came about, the unstable Daewoo Group plummeted. It had to sell off nearly 50 division corporations, only focusing on the major companies.
Kim was on the list for the [[Interpol]] when he was in exile, because of how he left Daewoo with the insurmountable debt, to his employees etc...
He was arrested soon after he returned to South Korea on June 14, 2005, and apologized "for hurting the nation and accepted full responsibility for the collapse of the group, adding he is ready to accept whatever the authorities have in store for him," according to the [[Chosun Ilbo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200506/200506140028.html|title=Kim Woo-choong Must Prove He Is Sincere|date=2005-01-14|website=english.chosun.com|publisher=[[The Chosun Ilbo]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050617021214/http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200506/200506140028.html|archivedate=2005-06-17|deadurl=yes}}</ref> In May 2006 he was sentenced to 10 years in jail after being found guilty of charges including embezzlement and accounting fraud. 21 trillion won ($22bn) of his fortune was seized and he was fined an additional 10m won.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/5028708.stm|title=Daewoo boss gets 10 years in jail|date=30 May 2006|publisher=|via=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
Citing health concerns, his sentence was reduced to 8 and 1/2 years; then on 30 December 2007, he was granted amnesty by President [[Roh Moo-hyun]]. South Korean presidents traditionally hand out pardons for the new year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-korea-pardons-idUSSEO20431320071231|title=S.Korea pardons Daewoo founder, death-row inmates|last=Herskovitz|first=Jon|last2=Lee|first2=Jin-joo|date=2007-12-31|publisher=Reuters}}</ref>
==See also== * Podcast on Kim Woo Choong's Autobiography - [https://vimeo.com/44615384 Every Street Is Paved With Gold] * [[Economy of South Korea]] * [[List of Korea-related topics]] * [[List of Koreans]]
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Lauritz Jenssen Dorenfeldt ''' (23 January 1863 – 3 January 1932) was a Norwegian engineer.
==Personal life== He was born in [[Strinda]] as the oldest of seven sons of businessman [[Lauritz Jenssen]] (1837–1899) and Jørgine Wilhelmine Darre (1842–1910). He was a brother of [[Hans Jørgen Darre-Jenssen]]<ref name=nbl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Lauritz J Dorenfeldt|encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Ingar|last=Kaldal|editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Lauritz_J_Dorenfeldt/utdypning|language=Norwegian|accessdate=5 December 2010}}</ref> and [[Worm Hirsch Darre-Jenssen]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nsd.uib.no/polsys/index.cfm?urlname=polsys&lan=&MenuItem=N1_1&ChildItem=&State=collapse&UttakNr=33&person=10597|title=Worm Hirsch Darre-Jenssen|publisher=Norwegian Social Science Data Services (NSD)|language=Norwegian|accessdate=5 December 2010}}</ref> and a nephew of [[Hans Jørgen Darre]]. He took the name Dorenfeldt in 1890.<ref name=nbl/>
In October 1890 he married physician's daughter Aagot Bødtker (1869–1963). They had the son [[Lauritz Jenssen Dorenfeldt (jurist)|Lauritz Jenssen Dorenfeldt]], who made his career in law.<ref name=nbl/> Through his wife he was also a brother-in-law of [[Sigurd Bødtker]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Sigurd Bødtker|encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Lise|last=Lyche|editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Sigurd_B%C3%B8dtker/utdypning|language=Norwegian|accessdate=5 December 2010}}</ref>
==Career== He took the [[examen artium]] at [[Trondheim Cathedral School|Trondhjem Cathedral School]] in 1881, and graduated from Trondhjem's technical school in 1884. He was hired in his father's factory [[Ranheim Cellulosefabrik]] in 1884, was promoted to assistant engineer in 1885 and manager in 1888. By that time he had undertaken studies at the [[Berlin Institute of Technology|Royal Technical College of Charlottenburg]]. In 1891 the factory became the paper factory [[Ranheim Papirfabrikk]]. In 1894 he was hired as a technical director for a similar factory in [[Worms, Germany|Rheindürkheim]], [[Rhineland Palatinate]], and in 1902 he settled in [[Oslo|Kristiania]] to work with technical consulting.<ref name=nbl/>
He was prominent in the development of [[pulp and paper industry]]. In the technical sphere, he was a proponent for using [[pyrite]] from Norway as well as [[natrium sulphite]] in the production of [[cellulose]]. He took part in a development of the Norwegian industry from exporting cellulose and [[Pulp (paper)|pulp]], to refining and exporting paper. He co-founded a research institute in 1922 and the association ''Norsk Celluloseforening''. He died in January 1932 in Oslo.<ref name=nbl/>

{{Orphan|date=August 2017}}
'''Luc Hoebeke''' (born 27 December 1941) is a [[Belgian]] consultant, author and lecturer in the field of self-organization, innovation processes and human activity systems, known for his book ''Making Work Systems Better: A Practitioner's Reflections'' (1994).<ref>Ten Bos, René. ''Fashion and utopia in management thinking''. Vol. 6. John Benjamins Publishing, 2000.</ref><ref>Arora, Sant, and Sameer Kumar. "Reengineering: a focus on enterprise integration." ''Interfaces'' 30.5 (2000): 54-71.</ref>
== Life and work == Born in [[Kortrijk, Belgium]], Hoebeke received his [[Master of Science in Engineering]] in Electrical Engineering, Nuclear Physics and Management Science.<ref name = "SV 2010">Gerrit Jan Schuiling, Johannes Gerardus Vermaak (eds.) ''Leren in organisaties: als leren het antwoord is, wat is dan de vraag?''. Kluwer, 2010. p 383</ref>
He has been working as consultant, author and lecturer. He assisted the University of Amsterdam in the development of a curriculum for the new study of Information Management and new Media, and also assisted the University of Leiden similar developments. He has been lecturer at the Sioo, Dutch institute for management studies, and from 2002 to 2010 he has been lecturer at the [[University of Cape Town Graduate School of Business]].<ref name = "SV 2010"/>
Hoebeke has been active in the Metaphorum community and fora on the [[viable system model]] (VSM).
== Work == In his book ''Making Work Systems Better: A Practitioner's Reflections'' (1994) <ref name="LH 1994">Luc Hoebeke, ''Making Work Systems Better: A Practitioner's Reflections'', John Wiley & Sons, {{ISBN|0471942480}},1994</ref> he developed a work system model based on the insights of [[Peter Checkland]] and [[Brian Wilson (systems scientist)|Brian Wilson]] in [[soft systems methodology]], [[Humberto Maturana]] and [[Francisco Varela|Francisco Varela's]] development of [[autopoiesis theory]], and [[Anthony Stafford Beer|Stafford Beers']] development of the viable system model.
The notion of a work system is defined by Hoebeke as "... a purposeful definition of the real world in which people spend effort in more or less coherent activities for mutually influencing each other and their environment." <ref name="LH 1994"/>
In the work systems model Hoebeke describes the generic transformation processes, control information, audit information and development information for human activities using four overlapping time domains:<ref name="LH 1994"/> # Added-value domain: This domain spans periods between 1 day and 2 years in which processes are characterized by throughput time, volume requirements, quality requirements and price requirements. # Innovation domain: This domain spans periods between 1 and 10 years in which processes are characterized by desirability, feasibility, transferability and systemicity. # Value-systems domain: This domain spans periods between 5 and 20 years in which processes are generative, tolerant, dialectical and congruent. # Spiritual domain: This domain spans periods longer than 20 years, up to 50 years. The generic transformation process in this domain is: "To materialize through works of art or mere behaviour the universal understanding of one's own mortality".
The notion of a transformation process is central in Hoebeke's work. Hoebeke defined it as "... a basic purpose behind the work system and transforms a specified input into a specified output. The output must contain the input, which has been transformed during the process."{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
The mentioned time domains (added-value, innovation, value-systems and spiritual) are overlapping. To handle this overlap Hoebeke uses the concept of ''process levels'', of which there are seven to span the time between 1 day and 50 years. Process level is defined as: {{Quote|A process of a higher order is one whose output creates conditions for one of a lower order. Processes can be differentiated in a hierarchy. To avoid confusion with what is seen in organisational terms as hierarchical levels we call this the process level.<ref name="LH 1994"/>}}
Hoebeke also defined the following concepts in terms not found in contemporary management literature:<ref name="LH 1994"/> * Contributions of people * Responsibility and accountability * Clients, actors, owners (as stakeholders of the process) * Environmental constraints and [[Weltanschauung]] * The management process
To complete the models' dimensions Hoebeke defined three information processes: * Strategic: All information processes that contribute to management, we call strategic information processes. These create, convey and develop meaning to all people involved in a work system. * Control: Control information processes are those which lead to a corrective, regulative action by the people contributing to transformation processes. * Audit: Audit information processes are those that lead actors to a more profound understanding of why the process is carried out, what it does, with what means it is performed and how these means are used.
==Selected publications==
===Books=== * 1994, ''Making Work Systems Better: A Practitioner's Reflections'', John Wiley & Sons, [http://sprouts.aisnet.org/792/2/Hoebeke-Making_Work_Systems_Better_(13-10-04)b.pdf Diss. Internet edition 2000].
===Articles, a selection=== * Hoebeke, Luc. "From work ethics towards work esthetics: Work as art and technological choice." ''Human Systems Management'' 7.4 (1988): 333-340. * Hoebeke, Luc. "Measuring in organisations." ''Journal of applied systems analysis'' 17 (1990): 115-122. * Hoebeke, Luc. "Identity: the paradoxical nature of organizational closure." ''Kybernetes'' 35.1/2 (2006): 65-75. * Hoebeke, Luc. "Dilemmas and paradoxes in organizing change processes." ''Dynamics of organizational change and learning'' (2004): 149-172.

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = Mainstreet Bank Limited| logo = | type = [[Private company|Private]]| slogan = | foundation = 2011| location = [[Lagos]], [[Nigeria]] | key_people = '''Faith Tuedor-Matthews'''
[[Managing Director]] & [[CEO]] | num_employees = | assets = | revenue = | industry = [[Financial Services]]| products = [[Loans]], [[cheque|Checking]], [[Savings]], [[Investments]], [[Debit Cards]], [[Credit Cards]]| homepage = [http://www.mainstreetbanklimited.com/ mainstreetbanklimited.com] |predecessor = [[Afribank]]}} '''Mainstreet Bank Limited''' (MBL), also referred to as '''Mainstreet Bank''', was a [[commercial bank]] in [[Nigeria]]. It was acquired by [[Skye Bank|Skye Bank Plc]] in 2014.{{Cite web|url = https://www.skyebankng.com/about-skye/our-history|title = Skye Bank Plc History|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ==Overview== Mainstreet Bank is a large financial services provider in [[Nigeria]]. Mainstreet Bank Limited assumed the assets and liabilities of [[Afribank|Afribank Plc.]], which had an epochal beginning as one of the big four banks in Nigeria, since 20 October 1959. The bank has been an active player in the Nigerian interbank market, and has leveraged on the legacy bank’s over 51 years experience and goodwill in the financial services sector to become a distinguished commercial bank that contributes to national economic development. Currently, the bank operates 217 branches nationwide, with at least one branch in every city of the 36 states in the Nigerian federation ==History== Mainstreet Bank was formed in August 2011 by taking over the assets and some of the liabilities of the now defunct [[Afribank|Afribank Plc.]], whose commercial banking license was revoked. MBL was issued a commercial banking license on 5 August 2011.{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201108060011.html|title=Nigeria: Afribank, Spring Bank, Bank PHB Nationalised|last=Chima|first=Obinna|date=2011-08-06|work=This Day (Lagos)|access-date=2017-08-29}} In 2014, Skye Bank won the bid to acquire the 100 per cent ownership stake of Asset Management Corporation of Nigeria (AMCON) in Mainstreet Bank Limited.{{Cite web|url = https://www.skyebankng.com/about-skye/our-history|title = Skye Bank Plc History|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ==Ownership== {{asof|January 2012}}, the assets of Mainstreet Bank Limited are 100% owned by '''Asset Management Company of Nigeria''' (AMCON), an arm of the [[Federal Government of Nigeria]]. ==Subsidiaries== The bank maintains the following subsidiaries:{{Cite web|url=http://www.afribank.com/msbib.php|title=afribank.com - afribank Resources and Information. This website is for sale!|website=www.afribank.com|access-date=2017-08-29}} # Mainstreet Bank Insurance Brokers Limited - Founded in 1988 (100% shareholding) # Mainstreet Bank Securities Brokers Limited - Founded in 1994 (100% shareholding) # Mainstreet Bank Microfinance Bank Limited - Founded in 2009 (100% shareholding) # Mainstreet Bank Trustees & Asset Management Company Limited - Founded in 1991 (100% shareholding) # Mainstreet Bank Registrars - Founded in 2004 (100% shareholding) # Mainstreet Bank Capital Markets - (100% shareholding) # Mainstreet Bank Estate Company Limited (100% shareholding) # Mainstreet Bank Bureau De Change Limited (100% shareholding) # ANP International Finance Limited - Founded in 1987 (100% shareholding) ==Branch network== {{asof|June 2012}}, Mainstreet Bank, maintains a network of over 220 branches in all states of [[Nigeria]]{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201206110968.html|title=Nigeria: Mainstreet Bank Sets Strategic Agenda|last=Chima|first=Obinna|date=2012-06-11|work=This Day (Lagos)|access-date=2017-08-29}} ==Governance== The [[Managing Director]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of the bank is '''Faith Tuedor-Matthews'''. ==See also== * [[List of banks in Nigeria]] * [[Central Bank of Nigeria]] * [[Economy of Nigeria]] * [[Afribank]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mainstreetbanklimited.com/ Website of Mainstreet Bank Limited] *[http://www.cenbank.org/ Website of Central Bank of Nigeria] *[http://www.vanguardngr.com/2011/08/fg-appoints-mds-for-nationalised-banks/ Federal Government Appoints Leaders of Nationalised Banks] [[Category:Companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Lagos]] [[Category:Banks established in 2011]] [[Category:Companies established in 2011]] [[Category:Economy of Nigeria]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Nigeria]] [[Category:Companies based in Lagos]]

'''Marketing experimentation''' is a research method which can be defined as "the act of conducting such an investigation or test".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Definition of "experiment" {{!}} Collins English Dictionary|url = http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/experiment|website = www.collinsdictionary.com|accessdate = 2015-10-29}}</ref> It is testing a market that is segmented to discover new opportunities for organisations.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zU3YfJDPUjE|title = Marketing Experiments: From the Basics to the Cutting Edge|date = 18 September 2012|accessdate = 31 October 2015|website = YouTube|publisher = Wharton Analytics|last = McDonnell|first = Elia}}</ref> By controlling conditions in an experiment, organisations will record and make decisions based on [[consumer behaviour]]. '''Marketing experimentation''' is commonly used to find the best method for maximizing [[revenues]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.slideshare.net/nbairstow/marketing-research-design|title = Marketing Research Design|date = 8 July 2008|accessdate = 29 October 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/experiment.html|title = What is experiment? Definition and meaning|date = |accessdate = 28 October 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> through the acquisition of new [[customer]]s. For example; two groups of customers are exposed to different advertising (test). How did consumers react to advertising compared to the other group? (measurable). Did the advertising increase sales for each group? (result).
== Characteristics<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = 2. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C3soKJGOcSM|title = 0:29 / 24:53 Unit 7: MR2300 - Marketing Research - Primary Research: Experiments|date = 7 November 2014|accessdate = 28 October 2015|website = YouTube|publisher = |last = Tilley|first = Paul}}</ref> == There are three characteristics which are the make-up of a market experimentation: * '''Experimental subjects''' '''-''' Humans are usually participants in experiments. Subjects are divided into two or more groups and can be referred to as [[Focus Groups|focus groups]]. Subjects can be made up of a particular age group [[Demographic|(demographical)]], from a particular area [[Geographic information system|(geographical)]], or culture ([[Ethnography|ethnographic]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/19346/1/Market_Experimentation_in_a_Dynamic_Differentiated-Goods_Duopoly.pdf|title = MARKET EXPERIMENTATION IN A DYNAMIC DIFFERENTIATED-GOODS DUOPOLY|date = July 1999|accessdate = 23 October 2015|website = |publisher = |last = Keller|first = Godfrey}}</ref> * '''Conditions -''' Known as the independent variable where, conditions are tightly controlled and manipulated by the tester. * '''Effects -''' Are the results of the test known as the dependent variable. Results are measured and cannot be changed. If the tester wants to see different results they would have to change the conditions of the independent variable to measure the effects. To gain an accurate result from experiments, the experimenter must consider outside factors that could effect the dependent variable. Continuing from the advertising example above; did sales increase because of a festive seasons at that particular time.<ref name=":0" />
== Applied application ==
In marketing email marketing is popular<ref name=":1" /> it is more targeted and there are many testable features such as font, colour and pictures. By tailoring emails it gives the experimenter control over conditions. For example; promoting discounts to '''experimental subjects''' via email.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.slideshare.net/nbairstow/marketing-research-design|title = Marketing Research Design|date = 8 July 2011|accessdate = 29 October 2015|website = Slide Share|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
It is here the experimenter has control and sets '''conditions''' by sending one tailored email to one age group (subject A). The experimenter will send another tailored email to an older age group (subject B) offering the same promotion with a different presentation. The experiment so far is exposing group A and B to different advertising messages.
There are many measurable outcomes, a few are as follows: * How much time is spent on the site from the URL link in an email * Better measurement in purchase process than other mediums - Subject A and B using promotion codes from the email * Users unsubscribing Comparing the '''effects''' the experiment had on subject A and subject B will give the organisation more of an understanding of how these subjects have reacted when they received the email (if there was one) and their purchasing behaviour. The experimenter may wish to change the '''conditions''' of the test to measure the different outcomes.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.marketingexperiments.com/methodology-marketingexperiments.html|title = Methodology {{!}} Marketing Experiments|date = |accessdate = 30 October 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Marvin Bower | image = Marvin Bower.jpg | image size = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1903|8|1}} | birth_place = [[Cincinnati|Cincinnati, Ohio]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2003|1|22|1903|8|1}} | death_place = [[Delray Beach, Florida]] | occupation = [[Consultant]], [[management]] expert }}
'''Marvin Bower''' (August 1, 1903 – January 22, 2003) was an American business theorist and management consultant.
== Biography == Bower was the son of the deputy recorder at [[Cuyahoga County]], and grew up in the [[Collinwood]] neighborhood of [[Cleveland, Ohio]] and attended [[Glenville High School]]. He earned his bachelor's degree in Economics and Psychology from [[Brown University]] in 1925. His father advised him to study law, and Bower graduated from [[Harvard Law School]] in 1928. Bower then attended [[Harvard Business School]], graduating in 1930. Following completion of his studies, Bower worked as an associate at [[Jones Day|Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue]] in Cleveland.
In 1933, Bower was hired by [[James O. McKinsey]] in the new [[Chicago]] firm of James O. McKinsey & Company to manage a newly acquired branch in [[New York City|New York]]. Following McKinsey's death in 1937, the two offices split up and Bower resurrected the New York firm, with the assistance of New York partners, as [[McKinsey & Company]] in 1939. He served as managing director from 1950 to 1967, and remained a leadership figure at McKinsey as director and partner until 1992.
According to the [[Harvard Business School]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Marvin Bower|url=http://www.hbs.edu/leadership/database/leaders/marvin_bower.html|publisher=Harvard Business School|accessdate=3 September 2011}}</ref> Bower "is considered the father of modern [[management consulting]]." His principled insistence on impeccable professional standards in substance, ethics, and style; his dedication to the professional development of his colleagues; and his candor, all served as a role model for several generations of management consultants, both within and outside McKinsey.
Bower performed one act in the history of McKinsey & Company that permanently set him and McKinsey apart from its competitors. In an era when other consultants were taking themselves public or selling out to larger companies, he sold his own shares back to the firm at book value when he turned 60, which he could easily have done at some huge multiple of earnings.
Bower's decision came as a surprise to many, including his own family. "Let me just say there was a shock on people's faces when he told us that he was selling his shares back to McKinsey at book value," said his son Dick Bower. "It felt unbelievable, to tell you the truth. But that was Marvin for you."<ref>Duff McDonald. ''The Firm: The Story of McKinsey and Its Secret Influence on American Business.'' 2014. p. 32</ref>
== Publications == He published several books and articles, among them: * ''The Will to Manage: Corporate Success Through Programmed Management'' (McGraw-Hill, New York, 1966), {{ISBN|0-07-006735-X}} * ''The Will to Lead: Running a Business With a Network of Leaders'' (Harvard Business School Press, Boston, Mass., 1997), {{ISBN|0-87584-758-7}} * ''Perspective on McKinsey'' - internal McKinsey publication
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Wikiquote|Marvin Bower}} * [http://www.marvinbower.org/ Marvin Bower: A Leader's Leader]
