'''Moshe Yanai''' ({{lang-he|משה ינאי}}; born 1949) is an [[Israelis|Israeli]] [[electrical engineer]]. He is an [[Patent|inventor]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100815193122/http://www.prior-ip.com/search#2;inventors%253A%2522moshe+yanai%2522+ Moshe Yanai's patents at prior-ip.com] Retrieved 5-27-2011.</ref> businessman, [[entrepreneur]],<ref name=Calcalist2010/> [[aviator]] (pilot),<ref>[http://www.themarker.com/tmc/article.jhtml?ElementId=skira20100902_1187608 "הג'וב החדש של משה ינאי: יטיס אנשי עסקים במסוק - The new job of Moshe Yanai: Will fly businessmen by helicopter"] ''TheMarker'', September 2, 2010 (in Hebrew; for a printer friendly version click [http://www.themarker.com/ibo/misc/printFriendly.jhtml?ElementId=skira20100902_1187608 here]; for an English version use, e.g., Google Web-page translation). Retrieved 11-13-2010.</ref> [[investor]],<ref name=Calcalist2010/><ref name=Diligent1>[http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/emc-transfers-its-r-d-to-diligent-1.28649 "EMC transfers its R&D to Diligent"] ''HA'ARETZ'', November 12, 2002 (for a printer friendly version click [http://www.haaretz.com/misc/article-print-page/emc-transfers-its-r-d-to-diligent-1.28649?trailingPath=2.169%2C2.225%2C2.228%2C here]). Retrieved 11-13-2010.</ref> and [[philanthropist]].<ref>[http://www.focus.technion.ac.il/Oct10/newsStory6.htm "Mr Nice Guy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816232837/http://www.focus.technion.ac.il/Oct10/newsStory6.htm |date=2011-08-16 }} ''TechnionFOCUS'', October 2010. Retrieved 12-16-2010.</ref><ref name=Birds2011>[http://www.jpost.com/NationalNews/Article.aspx?id=197149 "New bird research fund to take flight next week"] ''The Jerusalem Post'' 11/29/2010.</ref> He led the development of the [[EMC Symmetrix]], the [[flagship product]] of [[EMC Corporation]] in the 1990s.
== Biography == Moshe Yanai was born in 1949 in [[Israel]], and earned a [[B.Sc.]] in electrical engineering in 1975 from [[Technion - Israel Institute of Technology]]. Yanai began his career building [[IBM mainframe|IBM-compatible mainframe]] [[Data storage device|data storage]] based on [[minicomputer]] [[Disk storage|disks]] for [[Elbit Systems]] (a joint project with [[Nixdorf Computer]]). He went on to develop high-end storage systems for Nixdorf in the [[United States]].
Yanai joined [[EMC Corporation]] in 1987, and managed the [[EMC Symmetrix|Symmetrix]] development, [[Computer software|software]] and [[Computer hardware|hardware]], from its inception in the late 1980s<ref name=AxxanaBoard>[http://www.axxana.com/Axxana/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=137&FID=807 Axxana board of directors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100120065124/http://www.axxana.com/Axxana/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=137&FID=807 |date=2010-01-20 }} See Moshe Yanai. Retrieved 2-26-2011.</ref> until shortly before leaving EMC in 2001.<ref name=EMCfellow2001>EMC Company Web site, November 29, 2001: [http://www.emc.com/about/news/press/us/2001/20011129-1164.htm "EMC Strengthens Operational Alignment"] See paragraph about Moshe Yanai. Retrieved 10-24-2010.</ref> His development team grew from several people, recruited among his former Israeli colleagues, to thousands, while he was vice president.<ref name=AxxanaBoard/> EMC grew in the 1990s, both in size and value, from a company with a fading business of ([[minicomputer]]) [[computer memory]] [[Printed circuit board|boards]], valued in several millions of [[United States dollar|dollars]], to a hundreds-of-billions company.<ref>EMC Company Web site, July 19, 2000: [http://www.emc.com/about/news/press/us/earnings/20000719-469.htm "EMC Reports 43% Growth in Storage Revenue, First $2 Billion Quarter"] Retrieved 10-24-2010.</ref><ref>EMC Corp. at Yahoo Stock - Historical Prices [https://finance.yahoo.com/echarts?s=EMC+Interactive#] Retrieved 04-30-2015.</ref> Before leaving he became an EMC Fellow.<ref name=EMCfellow2001/>
Yanai funded and led an [[Israel]]i [[Computer storage|storage]] [[startup company]], XIV,<ref>[http://www.xivstorage.com/ XIV Storage Web site] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120919164845/http://www.xivstorage.com/ |date=2012-09-19 }} Retrieved 11-11-2010.</ref> which was bought by [[IBM]] in January 2008 (IBM paid an estimated $300 million for a company invested in with an estimated $3 million).<ref name=XIVIBM>[http://features.techworld.com/storage/3912/why-did-ibm-buy-xiv "Why did IBM buy XIV? IBM's XIV Purchase background"], ''TecWorld'', January 4, 2008. Retrieved 11-11-2010.</ref> Yanai continued leading XIV<ref>XIV Storage Web site: [http://www.xivstorage.com/about/about_profile.asp about] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101119021225/http://www.xivstorage.com/about/about_profile.asp |date=2010-11-19 }} Retrieved 2-26-2011.</ref> and became an [[IBM Fellow]].<ref name=IBMfellow2008>IBM Company Web site: [http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/photo/24265.wss IBM Fellow Moshe Yanai], Retrieved 11-11-2010.</ref> The [[IBM XIV Storage System]] became an IBM storage product.<ref name=IBMXIV>IBM Company Web site: [http://www-03.ibm.com/systems/storage/disk/xiv/ IBM XIV Storage System] Retrieved 3-1-2011.</ref> Shortly later, in April 2008, IBM bought Diligent Technologies,<ref name=Diligent2>IBM Company Web site: Press release 18 April 2008 [http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/23929.wss IBM Acquires Storage Company Diligent Technologies] Retrieved 3-1-2011.</ref> another storage company co-founded by Yanai.<ref name=Diligent1/> He left IBM in 2010.<ref name=Calcalist2010>[http://www.calcalist.co.il/local/articles/0,7340,L-3416970,00.html "ינאי נתן, ינאי לקח - Yanai gave, Yanai took"] ''Calcalist'', September 7, 2010 (In Hebrew; a printer friendly version [http://www.calcalist.co.il/Ext/Comp/ArticleLayout/CdaArticlePrintPreview/1,2506,L-3416970,00.html here]; for an English version use, e.g., Google Web-page translation). Retrieved 11-11-2010.</ref> In 2011 he founded [[Infinidat]], a [[computer data storage]] company. In April 2015, Infinidat announced a $150 million investment led by [[TPG Capital]].<ref>INFINIDAT Website, April 30, 2015: [http://www.infinidat.com/infinidat-announces-150-million-investment-led-by-tpg-eclipses-1b-valuation/ a $150 million investment "Infinidat Announces $150 Million Investment Led by TPG, Eclipses $1B Valuation"] Retrieved 04-30-2015.</ref> This investment placed it among the most valuable privately held companies.<ref>Wall Street Journal, April 30, 2015: [https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2015/04/29/data-storage-startup-infinidat-raises-150-million-at-1-2-billion-valuation/ "Data Storage Startup Infinidat Raises $150 Million at $1.2 Billion Valuation"] Retrieved 04-30-2015.</ref>
Yanai is an inventor or co-inventor of about 40 US patents in the field of electronic data storage.
In June 2011 his [[Alma mater]], [[Technion - Israel Institute of Technology]], awarded him the honor Distinguished Fellow of the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, and in 2012, conferred upon him an Honorary Doctorate. He has been a [[board of directors]] member of several companies.<ref name=AxxanaBoard/> Also in 2011, Infinidat announced Moshe became its CEO.<ref>http://www.infinidat.com/news/press-releases/infinidat-announces-150-million-investment-led-by-tpg-eclipses-1b-valuation/</ref>
== Awards ==
* [[EMC Corporation|EMC]] Fellow – 2001<ref name=EMCfellow2001/> * [[IBM Fellow]] – 2008.<ref name=IBMfellow2008/> * [[IEEE Reynold B. Johnson Information Storage Systems Award]] – 2010<ref>[http://www.ieee.org/about/awards/bios/johnson_info_recipients.html IEEE Reynold B. Johnson Information Storage Systems Award - 2010 to Moshe Yanai] Retrieved 12-16-2010.</ref> * Distinguished Fellow of the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, [[Technion - Israel Institute of Technology]] – 2011 * Honorary Doctorate, [[Technion - Israel Institute of Technology]] – 2012

OTV now covers the world through different broadcasting channels for [[European Union]], Canada, United States, Australia, and the [[Arab World]]. In addition, www.otv.com.lb offers live streaming coverage on the internet. OTV (Holding) SAL is a recently incorporated investment company; its purpose is to set up, develop, promote, equip, manage, support and/or finance specialized affiliate entities operating in related {{Infobox company | name = Option | logo = | image = Option HQ 2.jpg | image_caption = Option Headquarters in Leuven, Belgium | company_type = [[Public company|Public]] – [[Naamloze Vennootschap|NV]]
([[Euronext]]: [http://www.euronext.com/trader/summarizedmarket/stocks-2593-EN-BE0003836534.html?selectedMep=3&idInstrument=49797 OPTI]) | foundation = Leuven, Belgium (1986) | location_city = Leuven | location_country = Belgium | key_people = [[Jan Callewaert]], Founder in 1986 & current CEO | num_employees = 38 as of 2016[http://www.vfb.be/vfb/Media/Default/archief_pers/option/OPTION%20RAPPORTEERT%20JAARCIJFERS%20(8.3.2017).pdf] | industry = [[Telecommunication]]s, [[Wireless]] technology | products = [[PC card|Data card]]s
[[Embedded system|Embedded]] wireless modules
[[Mobile computing|Mobile]] connectivity devices
[[Software]] | revenue = {{profit}} €4.3 million (2016)[http://www.option.com/Upload/main/annual%20reports/Option_AR_2010_LR.pdf Option − Annual Report 2010] | net_income = {{loss}} €7.5 million (2016) | homepage = [http://www.option.com/ www.option.com] }} '''Option''' is a publicly quoted technology [[company]], headquartered in [[Leuven]], [[Belgium]]. Option specializes in the design, development, production and commercialization of [[broadband]] [[wireless]] technology devices. Option has been awarded [[Ernst & Young]]'s ‘Company of the Year’ award for 2005.[http://www.leuveninc.com/SITE/UPLOAD/DOCUMENT/Option_CoYe.pdf Press communication Ernst & Young] == Products == Remarkable was the GlobeTrotter Fusion+ card which was the first[http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/cgi/news/release?id=163773 Monday 13 February 2006 PRNewswire] to integrate [[HSDPA]]/[[UMTS]]/[[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]]/[[Wi-Fi]] technologies on a single data card. Option was the worldwide market leader in the wireless broadband [[Niche market|niche]] (other market contestants are either significantly smaller, or don’t consider wireless broadband a [[core business]] – for example [[NEC Corporation]]), and could benefit from high margins across the whole product range. Intentions from a new [[Intel]]-[[Nokia]] partnership which would deteriorate Option's market share were short-lived and quickly dropped,[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB111836437403956044?mod=technology_main_whats_news Nokia, Intel Plan to Collaborate On Wireless Technology WiMAX][http://www.unstrung.com/document.asp?doc_id=105059 Intel/Nokia Deal Gets Mixed Reactions][http://www.computerwire.com/industries/research/?pid=95B66072-C21B-4200-816A-E38141A28F76 Datamonitor ComputerWire - Nokia-Intel 3G Deal Threatens Wireless Modem Makers][http://www.boursorama.com/forum/message.phtml?file=356524043&pageForum=1 Dutch press coverage at 3GSM Barcelona, quoting an Intel spokesman] proving Option's leadership as well as high entry-to-market barriers even for large corporations. Most production took place at [[Jabil]] in [[Bergamo]], Italy, while [[Celestica]] in Kladno, [[Czech Republic]], provides additional capacity. Nowadays, all manufacturing of devices is done in [[Wuxi]] ([[China]]). The products were marked as having been designed in Leuven, but actually are refurbished and labelled in Ireland. == Financials == Initial market panic stemming from the announced Intel-Nokia deal did cause Option's share price to drop significantly in 2006, losing more than 23% in one day on September 28, which lies, together with the severe Chinese competition, at the basis of the downfall of the company . == Customers == Option's revenues substantially declined last years. In the past, Option had the following customers in their portfolio [[Sharp Corporation]], [[Wataniya Telecom]], [[Fujitsu Siemens Computers|Fujitsu Siemens]], [[T-Mobile]], [[Cingular]] Wireless (now AT&T), [[Vodafone]], [[Orange SA|Orange]], [[Bharti Airtel|Airtel]], [[Telstra]], [[Acer Inc.|Acer]], [[Uniwill]], [[Samsung Electronics]] and [[Telenor]], to name but a few. ==References and footnotes== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.option.com}} *[http://contrib.xarli.net/optionfusionsousdebian/ Usage of a GlobeTrotter Fusion+ card under Debian] *[http://www.dovado.com/ DOVADO routers supporting Option USB modems] *[http://www.infoferenda.eu/index.php?page=shop.browse&category_id=2&option=com_virtuemart&Itemid=2 External antennas for Option's USB and PC-card modems] [[Category:Companies based in Flemish Brabant‎]] [[Category:Telecommunications companies of Belgium]] [[Category:Companies established in 1986]] [[Category:Telecommunications equipment vendors]] [[Category:Naamloze_vennootschappen]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Euronext exchanges]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Belgium]]

revision.text:
{{COI|date=January 2012}} '''Policy alienation''' refers to a framework which examines the experiences of governmental employees with new policies they have to implement. It has been used to describe the experiences of front-line public professionals with new policies. It is defined "as a general cognitive state of psychological disconnection from the policy programme being implemented."
==Introduction== A number of examples can clarify the concept of policy alienation. For example, Bottery (1998:40),<ref>{{cite book|last=Bottery|first=M.|title=Professionals and policy: Management strategy in a competitive world|year=1998|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0-304-70157-2|url=https://www.amazon.com/Professionals-Policy-Management-Competitive-Education/dp/0304701572}}</ref> examining the pressures on professionals stemming from new policies in education and [[health care]] in Great Britain, cites a teacher arguing that: “The changes have been outrageous, and have produced a culture of meritocracy and high flyers. There’s massive paperwork because the politicians don’t believe teachers are to be trusted.” This indicates that professionals had difficulties identifying with the policies they had to implement. A second example refers to the introduction of a new reimbursement policy in mental healthcare in the Netherlands. In one large-scale survey, as many as nine out of ten professionals wanted to abandon this new policy (Palm et al., 2008).<ref>{{cite book|last=Palm, I., Leffers, F., Emons, T., Van Egmond, V., & Zeegers, S.|title=De GGz ontwricht: Een praktijkonderzoek naar de gevolgen van het nieuwe zorgstelsel in de geestelijke gezondheidszorg|year=2008|publisher=SP|location=The Hague|url=http://www.sp.nl/service/rapport/081025GGZ_ontwricht.pdf}}</ref> Psychologists even went as far as to openly demonstrate on the street against this policy. A major reason for this was that many could not align their professional values with the content of the policy. As one professional noted:
''"Within the new healthcare system economic values are dominant. Too little attention is being paid to the content: professionals helping patients. The result is that professionals become more aware of the costs and revenues of their behavior. This comes at the expense of acting according to professional standards.”''{{Attribution needed|date=June 2012}}
Overall, a number of studies show an increasing discontent among public professionals toward public policies (see also Hebson et al., 2003; White, 1996),<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hebson, G., Grimshaw, D., & Marchington, M.|title=PPPs and the changing public sector ethos: Case-study evidence from the health and local authority sectors|journal=Work Employment and Society|year=2003|volume=17|issue=3|pages=481–501|doi=10.1177/09500170030173005|url=http://wes.sagepub.com/content/17/3/481.short|accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=White, D.|title=A balancing act: Mental health policy-making in Quebec|journal=International Journal of Law and Psychiatry|year=1996|volume=19|issue=4|pages=289–307|pmid=8968814|doi=10.1016/s0160-2527(96)80005-7}}</ref> although more positive experiences can also be found (Ruiter, 2007).<ref>{{cite book|last=Ruiter, A. E. P.|title=Implementatie van het structureel echoscopisch onderzoek: Samenwerking en kwaliteitsdenken|year=2007|publisher=University of Twente|location=Twemte|url=http://essay.utwente.nl/58027/}}</ref> The policy alienation framework was developed to better understand the experiences of front-line public professionals with new policies.
==Effects of policy alienation== Currently, there is an intense debate concerning professionals in the public sector. Many of the pressures that professionals face are related to the difficulties they have with the policies they have to implement.<ref>{{cite book|editors=Duyvendak, W. G. J., Knijn, T., & Kremer, M.|title=Policy, people, and the new professional. de-professionalisation and re-professionalisation in care and welfare|year=2006|publisher=[[Amsterdam University Press]]|location=Amsterdam|isbn=978-90-5356-885-9}}</ref> When implementers are unable to identify with a policy, this can negatively influence policy effectiveness. Furthermore, a high degree of policy alienation can affect the quality of interactions between professionals and citizens, which may eventually influence the output legitimacy of government.<ref>{{cite book|authors=Bekkers, V. J. J. M., Edwards, A., Fenger, M., & Dijkstra, G.|title=Governance and the Democratic Deficit, assessing the legitimacy of governance practices|year=2007|publisher=Aldershot|location=Ashgate|isbn=0-7546-4983-0}}</ref> The policy alienation framework is used to analyze this topic.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tummers|first=L.G. |author2=Bekkers, V.J.J.M. |author3=Steijn, A.J.|title=Policy alienation of public professionals: Application in a new public management context|journal=Public Management Review|year=2009|volume=11|issue=5|pages=685–706|doi=10.1080/14719030902798230|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14719030902798230}}</ref> It has been shown that policy alienation increases resistance to a new policy, lowers behavioral support for the policy and decreases job satisfaction of public professionals.<ref>{{cite book|last=Tummers, L.G.|title=Policy alienation - Analyzing the experiences of public professionals with new policies|year=2012|publisher=Erasmus University Rotterdam|location=Rotterdam}}</ref> Hence, it has both influences on the individual professional, as well as on policy effectiveness.
== Conceptualization == Alienation broadly refers to a sense of social estrangement, an absence of social support or meaningful social connection. Sociologists, [[public administration]] scholars, and other social scientists have used the alienation concept in various studies. As a result, a number of meanings have been attributed to the term.<ref name=Kanungo>{{cite book|last=Kanungo|first=R.|title=Work alienation: an integrative approach|year=1982|publisher=Praeger Publishers|location=New York|isbn=978-0-03-060241-2}}</ref> In an attempt to provide clarity, Seeman broke these meanings down into [[Social alienation|five alienation dimensions]]: powerlessness, meaninglessness, normlessness, social isolation, and self-estrangement.
Many scholars have used these dimensions to devise operational measures for alienation so that they can examine the concept in a range of settings. Mau, for example, used four dimensions in examining student alienation. Rayce et al., when investigating adolescent alienation, used three of the five dimensions. Further, many other researchers have used Seeman’s classification in examining the concept of work alienation. [[Bob Blauner|Blauner]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Blauner, R.|title=Alienation and freedom|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago}}</ref> devised operational measures for three of the dimensions: powerlessness, meaninglessness, and social isolation.
The policy alienation framework was conceptualized based on the works of sociologists such as [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegel]], [[Karl Marx|Marx]], Seeman, and Blauner. Furthermore, works of public administration scholars were used, particularly on [[Michael Lipsky|Lipsky]] (street-level bureaucracy). Like work alienation, policy alienation is multidimensional, consisting of policy powerlessness and policy meaninglessness dimensions. In the work alienation literature, the dimensions of powerlessness and meaninglessness are also considered very important.<ref name=Kanungo />
In essence, powerlessness is a person's lack of control over events in their life. In the realm of policy formulation and implementation, policy powerlessness relates to the degree of influence public professionals have over shaping a policy program. Powerlessness can occur when a new policy is drafted without the help of the professionals, by for example not consulting their professionals associations or labor unions. Furthermore, on an operational level professionals can feel powerless when they have to adhere to tight procedures and rules when implementing a policy (see also [[Michael Lipsky|Lipsky]]). This kind of powerlessness may be particularly pronounced in professionals whose expectations of discretion and autonomy contradict notions of bureaucratic control (see also [[Profession]]).<ref>{{cite book|last=Freidson, E.|title=Professionalism: The third logic|year=2001|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=0-226-26203-0|url=https://www.amazon.com/Professionalism-Third-Logic-Practice-Knowledge/dp/0226262030}}</ref>
The second dimension of policy alienation is meaninglessness. In the realm of policy making and implementation, policy meaninglessness refers to a professional’s perception of the contribution that the policy makes to a greater purpose, most notably to society or to their own clients. For instance, a professional can feel that implementing a policy is meaningless, if it does not deliver any apparent beneficial outcomes for society, such as more safety on the streets.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Van Thiel, S., & Leeuw, F. L.|title=The performance paradox in the public sector|journal=Public Performance and Management Review|year=2002|volume=25|issue=3|pages=267–281|doi=10.2307/3381236|url=http://repub.eur.nl/res/pub/1577/BSK074.pdf}}</ref>
To make the dimensions more specific, five sub-dimensions were identified: strategic, tactical and operational powerlessness, societal and client meaninglessness. This is shown in the table below.
'''Five sub-dimensions of policy alienation''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! Sub-dimension !! Definition !! Example of high scores |- | Strategic powerlessness || The perceived influence of the professionals on decisions concerning the content of the policy, as is captured in rules and regulations || A professional feeling that the policy is drafted without the help of implementing professionals or professional associations. |- | Tactical powerlessness || The professionals’ perceived influence on decisions concerning the way policy is implemented within their own organization. || Professionals stating that the managers in the organization did not consult them or their colleagues when designing the implementation process for the policy. |- | Operational powerlessness || The perceived degree of freedom in making choices concerning the sort, quantity and quality of sanctions and rewards on offer when implementing the policy. || Answering ‘fully agree’ to a survey question on whether the professional feels that their autonomy during the implementation process was lower than it should be. |- | Societal meaninglessness || The perception of professionals concerning the added value of the policy to socially relevant goals. || Stating in an interview that “I agree with the policy goal of enhancing transparency, but I do not see how this policy helps in achieving this goal.” |- | Client meaninglessness || The professionals’ perceptions of the added value of their implementing a policy for their own clients. || A professional who argues that a particular policy seriously impinges on their clients’ privacy. |}
==See also== *[[Anomie]] *[[Marx's theory of alienation]] *[[Political alienation]] *[[Social comparison theory]] *[[Public management]]
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Infobox company | name = Santika Indonesia Hotels & Resorts | logo = Santika Indonesia Hotels & Resorts logo.svg | type = [[Private company|Private]] | industry = [[Hotel]], [[tourism]] | parent = [[Kompas Gramedia]] | foundation = August 22, 1981 | locations = 44 | homepage = {{URL|http://www.santika.com/}} }}
'''Santika Indonesia Hotels & Resorts''' is one of the largest [[hotel]] chains in [[Indonesia]] and managed under PT. Grahawita Santika, a member of [[Kompas Gramedia]] Group. PT. Grahawita Santika was established on August 22, 1981 and has over 40 hotels across Indonesia. Since 2006, PT. Grahawita Santika has changed its strategy based on market segmentation and divided its brands into The Royal Collection, Hotel Santika Premiere, Hotel Santika, and Amaris Hotel.
==History== PT. Grahawita Santika was established to manage the hospitality industry under [[Kompas Gramedia]] Group on August 22, 1981. Hotel Soeti was the first hotel purchased from its owner, Soetiyah Pudjosuwarno. This hotel is on Jalan Sumatra No. 52-54, Bandung. In 1988, this simple hotel with 33 rooms built in an area of 3,250 square meters was renovated into 70 rooms. Once the renovation was completed, this hotel was inaugurated as the 3-star Hotel Santika Bandung by the Minister of Tourism, Post and Telecommunications, Susilo Sudarman on March 27, 1989. Hotel Santika Bandung was the forerunner to the establishment of Santika Indonesia Hotels & Resorts.<ref>{{cite web | title=History (Translated) | url=http://www.kompasgramedia.com/aboutkg/history | publisher=Kompas Gramedia Group | accessdate=2012-05-07}}</ref>
The background of the establishment of Hotel Santika, because ''[[Kompas]]'' daily newspaper was suppressed in 1978, therefore the pioneers of [[Kompas Gramedia]] Group should think about the business diversification outside its core business as a communication media. They made the plan in order to prevent mass layoffs. If the ''Kompas'' daily newspaper will be suppressed again, there are subsidiaries, which can sustain their employees. Several businesses began to implement, including the [[hospitality industry]].
At the beginning, the proposal for establishing a hotel was not approved because at that time, hotel business was considered a negative connotation and the [[Rate of return|Return on Investment]] was progressing slowly. However, Binawarman Sardjan, who was a member on the investment team of [[Kompas Gramedia]] Group at that time, could convince the Chairman of the investment team of [[Kompas Gramedia]] Group, Indra Gunawan, to approve the proposal. Because of the persistence and hard work of Binawarman Sardjan, Hotel Santika could be established.
Several years after the first Santika Hotel was inaugurated, Santika Indonesia Hotels & Resorts can develop itself and reach about 40 properties across Indonesia. In accordance with its brand value, "Indonesian Home" and the service motto, "Hospitality from the Heart", Santika Indonesia Hotels & Resorts always emphasize the value of Indonesian culture, including the hospitality to all guests.<ref name=corpinfo>{{cite web | title=History | url=http://www.santika.com/santika.php?gmid=1 | publisher=Santika Indonesia Hotels & Resorts | accessdate=2012-05-07 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120506231030/http://santika.com//santika.php?gmid=1 | archivedate=2012-05-06 | df= }}</ref>
==Hotels and resorts== Currently, Santika Indonesia Hotels & Resorts has four brands across Indonesia: The Royal Collection, Hotel Santika Premiere, Hotel Santika, and Amaris Hotel.<ref name=corpinfo/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.santika.com/}} * [http://www.amarishotel.com/ Amaris Hotel Indonesia]
{{hotel chains}}

{{use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Saud bin Nayef | image = | caption = | succession = Head of the Crown Prince Court | reign = November 2011 – 14 January 2013 | reign-type = In office | successor =[[Mohammad bin Salman Al Saud|Mohammad bin Salman]] | reg-type = Monarch | regent = [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]] | predecessor = Ali bin Ibrahim Al Hadeethi | succession1 = Saudi Arabia Ambassador to Spain | reign1 = 10 September 2003 – July 2011 | reign-type1 = In office | predecessor1 = Abdulaziz Al Thunayan{{cite web|title=Royal decrees on ministerial and top-level appointments|url=http://www.saudiembassy.net/archive/1997/news/page137.aspx|publisher=Saudi Embassy|accessdate=8 May 2012|date=7 June 1997}} | successor1 = Mansour bin Khaled bin Abdullah Al Farhan{{cite news|title=Prince Salman arrives in Spain|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=20120607126192|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610200437/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=20120607126192|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 June 2015|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Saudi Gazette|date=7 June 2012}} | succession2 = Governor of [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]] | reign2 = 14 January 2013 – present | reign-type2 = In office | regent2 = [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]] | reg-type2 = Appointed by | predecessor2 = [[Mohammed bin Fahd]] | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1956}} | birth_place = | spouse = Abeer bint Faisal bin Turki | issue = Jawahir
[[Abdulaziz bin Saud Al Saud|Abdulaziz]]
Mohammed
Nora
Sara | house = [[House of Saud]] | father = [[Nayef bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Nayef bin Abdulaziz]] | mother = Al Jawhara bint Abdulaziz bin Musaid Al Jiluwi }} '''Saud bin Nayef''' (born 1956) ({{lang-ar|سعود بن نايف بن عبد العزيز آل سعود}}) is the former head of the Crown Prince Court and special advisor to the Saudi Crown Prince. He is governor of [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia]] as well as a member of [[House of Saud]]. Prince Saud was once regarded as one of the candidates for king or crown prince when succession passed to the new generation.{{cite news|last=Knickmeyer|first=Ellen|title=Saudi Arabia's Enforcer of Internal Security|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303734204577470241545061170|accessdate=23 June 2012|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=16 June 2012}} == Early life and education== Prince Saud was born in 1956.{{cite book|author=Sabri Sharaf|title=The House of Saud in Commerce: A Study of Royal Entrepreneurship in Saudi Arabia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51Bb8Ix7xw8C&pg=PA124|accessdate=2 April 2013|year=2001|publisher=Sharaf Sabri|isbn=978-81-901254-0-6|page=129}} He is the eldest son and one of ten children of the former Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia, [[Nayef bin Abdulaziz]].{{cite book|author=Stig Stenslie|title=Regime Stability in Saudi Arabia: The Challenge of Succession|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-g81rF4Zga4C&pg=PA39|accessdate=7 December 2012|date=21 August 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-51157-8|page=39}} His mother is Al Jawhara bint Abdulaziz bin Musaid Al Jiluwi.{{cite web|title=Family Tree of Nayif bin Abdulaziz bin Abdul Rahman al Saud|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176787|work=Datarabia|accessdate=2 May 2012}}{{cite news|author=Caryle Murphy|title=The heir apparent|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/saudi-arabia/090504/Prince-Nayef-Abdul-Aziz|accessdate=5 May 2012|work=Global Post|date=5 June 2009}} She was a member of the powerful Jiluwi clan whose members have been intermarried with those of House of Saud,{{cite web|last=Teitelbaum|first=Joshua|title=Saudi succession and stability|url=http://www.biu.ac.il/SOC/besa/docs/perspectives153.pdf|work=BESA Center|accessdate=24 April 2012|date=1 November 2011}} and sister of [[King Fahd]]'s wife.{{cite news|last=Kechichian|first=Joseph|title=Saudi’s Eastern Province post of grave importance|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/saudi-s-eastern-province-post-of-grave-importance-1.1133253|accessdate=21 January 2013|work=Gulf News|date=16 January 2013}} [[Mohammed bin Nayef|Prince Mohammed]] is his younger brother.{{cite news|title=Saudi King Asks Saud Bin Nayef to Run Oil-Rich Province|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-14/saudi-king-asks-saud-bin-nayef-to-run-oil-rich-province.html|accessdate=22 January 2014|work=Bloomberg|date=14 January 2014|author=Glenn Carey}} Saud bin Nayef received a bachelor of arts degree in economics and management from the [[University of Portland]].{{cite web|title=Saud bin Nayef bin Abdulaziz|url=http://www.arabthought.org/en/cv/saud-bin-nayef-bin-abdul-aziz|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120719145720/http://www.arabthought.org/en/cv/saud-bin-nayef-bin-abdul-aziz|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 July 2012|work=Arab Thought Foundation|accessdate=29 April 2012}} ==Career and activities== Saud bin Nayef was appointed vice president of the youth welfare presidency in January 1986. However, he resigned after six months. Then he had business dealings.{{cite news|title=About the Bin Laden family|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/binladen/who/family.html|accessdate=26 February 2013|work=PBS}} In February 1993, he began to serve as the deputy governor of the Eastern Province and left business activities.{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Simon|title=After King Fahd|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/uploads/Documents/pubs/PP_37_AFTERKINGFAHD.pdf|work=Washington Institute|accessdate=2 February 2013|format=Policy Paper|year=1994}}{{cite web|title=Social Responsibility|url=http://www.projectssystemgroup.com/social_responsibility.html|publisher=Projects System Group|accessdate=5 May 2012}} His term lasted until 2003. Shortly after, he was appointed Saudi ambassador to [[Spain]] on 10 September 2003 and served as ambassador until July 2011.{{cite news|last=Carey|first=Glen|title=Saudi King Asks Saud Bin Nayef to Run Oil-Rich Province|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-14/saudi-king-asks-saud-bin-nayef-to-run-oil-rich-province.html|accessdate=20 April 2013|work=Bloomberg|date=14 January 2013}} While serving as ambassador he contributed to the organization of [[interfaith]] conference in [[Madrid]] that brought together Israeli and American [[rabbis]] and [[Wahhabi]] clerics in July 2008.{{cite news|title=Saudi king bringing rabbis, clerics together|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/25691473/ns/world_news-world_faith/#.USkdW6VSjm4|accessdate=23 February 2013|work=NBC News|date=15 July 2008|agency=AP|location=Madrid}} The conference was an initiative of King Abdullah. Next, Prince Saud was appointed assistant minister of interior for public affairs{{cite web|title=Change and succession in Saudi Arabia|url=http://www.mepc.org/articles-commentary/commentary/change-and-succession-saudi-arabia|work=Middle East Policy Council|accessdate=24 May 2012|author=Nathaniel Kern|author2=Matthew M. Reed |date=15 November 2011}}{{cite news|last=Khan|first=Ghazanfar Ali|title=We've a pious, capable king: Nayef|url=http://monsterpolitic.com/weve-a-pious-capable-king-naif|accessdate=12 April 2012|newspaper=Arab News|date=30 October 2012}} and advisor to then-second deputy prime minister, his father late [[Nayef bin Abdul Aziz Al Saud|Prince Nayef]] in July 2011.{{cite web|title=Prince Saud bin Nayef bin Abdulaziz appointed Assistant to Prince Nayef|url=http://www.saudiembassy.net/latest_news/news07031102.aspx|publisher=Royal Embassy, Washington D.C.|accessdate=24 May 2012|date=3 July 2011}} Saud bin Nayef was the head of the Crown Prince Court and special advisor to the Crown Prince at the rank of minister from November 2011 to 13 January 2013.{{cite web|title=Crown Prince receives Saudi envoys in Cleveland|url=http://www.moi.gov.sa/wps/portal/!ut/p/b1/04_Sj9CPykssy0xPLMnMz0vMAfGjzOJNnQOcPS18jQ3dA0LNDYzczE28nM28LQy8TfTD9aPwKjExhipwdnf0MDH3MTCw8HE3NfB09AgNsgw0NjZwhCkwwAEcDfT9PPJzU_ULsrODLBwVFQGRRnS5/dl4/d5/L2dJQSEvUUt3QS80SmtFL1o2X0dOVlMzR0gzMTBGSUUwSVFJSkozR1YzQ0w2/?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/wps/wcm/connect/main/moi+home+content/home/news/news+archive/moi_news_17-03-2012d_en|work=Ministry of Interior|accessdate=24 May 2012|date=17 March 2012}} He replaced Ali bin Ibrahim Al Hadeethi as head of the court.{{cite news|title=Al Hadeethi and Al Marri relieved of their posts, Prince Saud bin Nayef bin Abdulaziz and Al Rubaia replaced them|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Al-Hadeethi+and+Al-Marri+relieved+of+their+posts,+Prince+Saud+bin...-a0271747415|accessdate=29 April 2012|work=Saudi Agency Press|date=5 November 2011}}{{cite web|title=Prince Salman named Defense Minister, Prince Sattam appointed Riyadh Governor|url=http://www.saudiembassy.net/latest_news/news11051101.aspx|publisher=Saudi Embassy Washington DC|accessdate=7 May 2012|date=5 November 2011}} During his tenure, Prince Saud exercised the power given him through this appointment on behalf of his father rather than on his own authority. His term as the head of the court and special advisor to the Crown Prince continued after Prince Nayef's death in June 2012 for six months.{{cite web|title=Crown Prince Receives U.S. Secretary of Defense|url=http://www.spa.gov.sa/English/readsinglenews.php?id=1009638&content_id=&scroll=1|work=Saudi Press Agency|accessdate=22 June 2012|date=20 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014214423/http://www.spa.gov.sa/English/readsinglenews.php?id=1009638&content_id=&scroll=1|archivedate=14 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} On 13 January 2013, Prince Saud was appointed governor of the oil-rich Eastern province at the rank of minister, replacing [[Mohammed bin Fahd]].{{cite news|title=Saudi king names new governor for restive oil region|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/01/14/us-saudi-appointment-idUSBRE90D0FQ20130114|accessdate=14 January 2013|work=Reuters|date=14 January 2013|location=Jeddah}}{{cite news|last=Khazen|title=Prince Muqrin As I Have Known Him|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Ayoon+Wa+Azan+(Prince+Muqrin+As+I+Have+Known+Him).-a0317738367|accessdate=26 March 2013|work=Dar Al Hayat International|date=6 February 2013}} On the death of [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]] in 2015, he was passed over in the line of succession in favor of his younger brother Mohammed. ==Other roles and business activities== During his term as Saudi Ambassador to Spain, Prince Saud had contacts with president of the Madrid Stock Exchange.{{cite web|title=Beyond the crisis|url=http://www.scief.es/symposium.php|publisher=Saudi Spanish Center for Islamic Economics and Finance|accessdate=May 28, 2012}} He is one of the members of the board of trustees of the [[Arab Thought Foundation]] that is a Saudi think-tank group, attempting to improve the relations between Arab nations and the Western nations.{{cite web|title=Board of Trustees|url=http://www.arabthought.org/en/main/board-trustees|work=Arab Thought|accessdate=2 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523191242/http://www.arabthought.org/en/main/board-trustees|archivedate=23 May 2012|df=dmy-all}} Saud bin Nayef is also deputy chairman of the Higher Commission of the Prize of Prince Nayef bin Abdulaziz Al Saud for the Prophetic Sunnah and Islamic Studies and General Supervisor of the Prize.{{cite news|title=Prince Saud bin Nayef chairs meeting of higher commission of Islamic studies prize|url=http://www.gulfinthemedia.com/index.php?m=gcc_press&id=2411480&cnt=171&lang=en|accessdate=28 May 2012|work=Gulf in the Media|date=20 May 2012}} In addition to these semi-public roles, in December 2011, Saud bin Nayef was appointed member of the [[Allegiance Council]] since his father could not have a seat in the Council due to being then crown prince.{{cite web|last=Abdul Ghafour|first=P.K.|title=Saudi Arabia seeks global backing For Palestinians|url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/06122011-saudi-arabia-seeks-global-backing-for-palestinians/|work=Arab News|accessdate=29 April 2012|date=6 December 2011}} Saud bin Nayef has also some business activities. He has a stake in [[Dana Gas|Danagas corporation]].{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://www.danagas.com/en/member/about-us/boardandmanagement/founders/saudi-arabia.html|accessdate=25 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905172518/http://www.danagas.com/en/member/about-us/boardandmanagement/founders/saudi-arabia.html|archivedate=5 September 2014|df=dmy-all}} And he is the owner of [[SNAS Aviation|SNAS]] trading and contacting company.{{cite web|title=Application of SNAS|url=http://www.airlineinfo.com/Sites/DailyAirline/web-content/ostpdf37/670.pdf|publisher=Airline Info|accessdate=29 April 2012}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Personal life== Saud bin Nayef was married twice. First, to princess Abeer bint Faisal bin Turki. They have four children: Jawahir, [[Abdulaziz bin Saud Al Saud|Abdulaziz]] (born 1983, [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|interior minister]] since June 2017), Mohammed and Nora. He had another daughter; Sara, with his second wife, but the child died in infancy.{{cite web|title=Family Tree of Saud bin Nayef bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176790|publisher=Datarabia|accessdate=23 March 2012}} His son, Mohammed, is married to a daughter of [[Sultan bin Abdulaziz]]. One of Prince Saud's daughters married Faisal bin Saud bin [[Abdullah al Faisal|Abdullah Al Faisal]] in October 2010{{cite news|title=الأمير نايف يشرف حفل زواج الأمير فيصل بن سعود بن عبدالله الفيصل من كريمة الأمير سعود بن نايف|url=http://www.alriyadh.com/2010/10/04/article564895.html|accessdate=23 March 2012|newspaper=Al Riyadh|date=4 October 2010}} and the other married Nayef bin Sultan bin Abdulaziz on 10 December 2010.{{cite news|title=الأمير نايف بن سلطان يحتفل بزواجه من كريمة الأمير سعود بن نايف|url=http://www.alriyadh.com/2010/12/10/article583976.html|accessdate=23 March 2012|newspaper=Al Riyadh|date=10 December 2010}} His son, Mohammed bin Saud, has Al Naifat stable. He won the Belgium International championship and World Horse Producers Cup in the US in April 2012. He also won the Di Pietrasanta international B show{{cite web|title=Al Nayfat Stud achieved Italy Championship|url=http://www.alnayfatstud.net/en/?p=443|publisher=Al Nayfat Stud|accessdate=16 May 2012|date=14 May 2012}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} in May 2012. Two horses from the Al Naifat stable, Diana and Mascot, were chosen as the most beautiful horses among more than 100 Arab origin horses in the same event.{{cite news|title=Stables of Prince Muhammad bin Saud win in Italy|url=http://www.spa.gov.sa/English/readsinglenews.php?id=998190&content_id=&scroll=1|accessdate=16 May 2012|work=Saudi Press Agency|date=14 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924104308/http://www.spa.gov.sa/English/readsinglenews.php?id=998190&content_id=&scroll=1|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} ==Views== Concerning the business activities of the [[House of Saud|Al Saud]] family, Saud bin Nayef argued "You have to understand one simple fact. Since it (Al Saud Family) is a big family and we cannot all have government jobs, some have to make a living. That's only fair."{{cite book|title=Saudi Arabia: The coming storm|publisher=M. E. Sharpe|isbn=1-56324-394-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K_c9FOeeuewC&pg=PA23&lpg=PA23&dq=prince+saud+bin+nayef&source=bl&ots=3A6PL3tMj0&sig=8R0hpotkCRxZi5lzAmWgFyAlqJw&hl=tr&sa=X&ei=-0WHT463DovMswbT1dSSBA&ved=0CHQQ6AEwCDhk#v=onepage&q=prince%20saud%20bin%20nayef&f=false|author=Peter W. Wilson|author2=Douglas Graham |accessdate=13 April 2012|year=1994}} ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Saud bin Nayef'''{{cite web|title=Family Tree of Muhammad bin Nayef bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176793|work=Datarabia|accessdate=24 May 2012}} |2= 2. [[Nayef bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud]] |3= 3. al-Jawhara bint Abdulaziz bin Musaed bin Jiluwi |4= 4. [[Ibn Saud]] |5= 5. [[Hassa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi]] |6= 6. Abd al-Aziz bin Musaid bin Jiluwi Al Jiluwi |7= 7. Tarfa bint Musa'id bin Battal Al [[Mutayr]]i |8= 8. [[Abdul Rahman bin Faisal]] |9= 9. Sarah bint Ahmed al-Kabir bin Muhammad Al Sudairi |10= 10. Ahmed bin Muhammed Al Sudairy |11= 11. Sharifa bint Ali bin Muhammad Al Suwaidi |12= 12. Musaid bin Jiluwi bin Turki Al Jiluwi |13= 13. al-Jawhara bint Nasir bin Faysal Al Thunayyan |14= 14. Musa'id bin Battal Al Mutayri |16= 16. [[Faisal bin Turki bin Abdullah Al Saud]] |17= 17. Sarah bint Mishari bin Abdulrahman bin Hassan Al Saud |18= 18. Ahmed Al Kabir bin Muhammad bin Turki Al Sudairi |20= 20. Muhammed bin Ahmed Al Kabir Al Sudairi |22= 22. Ali bin Muhammad Al Suwaidi |24= 24. Jiluwi bin [[Turki bin Abdullah bin Muhammad|Turki]] bin [[Abdallah bin Muhammad bin Saud|Abdallah]] Al Jiluwi |25= 25. Nura bint Ahmad Al Sudairi |26= 26. Nasir bin Faysal bin Nasir Al Thunayyan |28= 28. Battal Al Mutayri }} == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before= [[Mohammed bin Fahd]] | after= Incumbent | title=Governor of East Province | years=2013 – present}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saud bin Nayef}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Saudi Arabia to Spain]] [[Category:Governors of provinces in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Grandsons of Ibn Saud|Nayef, Saud bin]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Portland alumni]]

revision.comment: +{{[[Template:Authority control|Authority control]]}} (1 source from Wikidata), [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=March 2016}} {{Notability|Biographies|date=March 2016}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Sergey Kuznetsov | image = Sergey Kuznetsov.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Kuznetsov in September 2010 | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1966|06|14}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]], Russia | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = Writer, journalist, entrepreneur | years_active = | URL = [http://www.skuzn.ru/ www.skuzn.ru] }} '''Sergey Yurievich Kuznetsov''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|Сергей Юрьевич Кузнецов}}; born 14 June 1966) is a contemporary Russian writer, journalist and entrepreneur.
==Early life== Kuznetsov was born in [[Moscow]] to Galina Kuznetsova, a French language and [[French literature]] teacher, and Yuri Kuznetsov, a well-known Soviet chemist. In 1988, Kuznetsov graduated from [[Moscow State University]]'s Department of Chemistry.
==Career==
===Literary career=== Throughout his early literary career, he focused on modern philology; his works included a monograph on [[Joseph Brodsky]]'s poetics as well as translations of [[Stephen King]] and [[Susan Sontag]]. He also studied the works of [[Thomas Pynchon]].
Kuznetsov's first published work was ''The Nineties: A Fairy Tale'', a detective trilogy. His first work to receive critical acclaim was ''PG-21'', a futuristic novel written together with [[Linor Goralik]] and nominated for the National Bestseller award.
Other books by Kuznetsov were also favored by the critics and were nominated for various literature awards. His [[Young adult fiction|young adult]] work ''Alive and Adult'' was awarded Best Book in Mystics & Horror of 2011 by [[Mir Fantastiki|World of SciFi (Mir Fantastiki) magazine]]; his novel ''Round-Dance of Water'' was shortlisted for ''Big Book'' (''Bolshaya Kniga''), a prominent Russian literary award.
Kuznetsov's books have been translated into many languages. ''Round-Dance of Water'', for instance, was published in Arabic, and several chapters from the book were published independently in the ''Moscow Noir'' anthology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akashicbooks.com/catalog/moscow-noir/|title=Moscow Noir (Russia)|publisher=}}</ref>
''Butterfly Skin''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://titanbooks.com/butterfly-skin-7346/|title=Titan Books - Butterfly Skin - Sergey Kuznetsov, Andrew Bromfield|publisher=}}</ref> was translated into English, German, Polish, Hungarian, Czech and Dutch. The publishers called it a Russian take on [[The Silence of the Lambs (novel)|''Silence of the Lambs'']], but critics pointed out that Kuznetsov "aims for more than smug nihilism. He delivers a gratifying conclusion to a sometimes overburdened and sickening journey through sadism and alienation."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/26/books/review/tawni-odells-one-of-us-and-more.html|title=Killer Company|date=26 October 2014|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
His most recent novel, "Kaleidoscope", received praise from both readers and critics. Lisa Hayden, a recognized literary translator, wrote: ‘What I enjoy is reading about upheaval and how it affects and even connects characters that pop in and out of the chapters like pieces in a kaleidoscope" <ref>{{cite web|url=https://catranslation.org/blog-post/lisa-hayden-on-russian-book-prizes/|title=Q&A: Lisa Hayden on the 2016 Russian Book Prizes|date=16 February 2017|work=Center for the Art of Translation}}</ref>
Member of [[PEN Club]] and Russian Union of Cinematographers.
===Journalism=== In 1996 he started to write articles on pop culture for various magazines and online media. After returning from Stanford to Russia in 2002, Kuznetsov continued to work in journalism.
Kuznetsov took part in forming post-Soviet independent journalism in Russia, focusing mainly on movies and literature. He contributed to Russian editions of [[Premiere (magazine)|''Premiere'']], ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'', [[Vogue (magazine)|''Vogue'']] and other magazines. He participated in multiple online projects.
In 2006, he launched ''[[Booknik]]'', a daily online project on Jewish literature and culture that took a hard-copy quarterly form from 2007 to 2013, called ''Booknik Reader''. In 2011, as editor-in-chief of the publication, Kuznetsov was awarded Man of the Year 5771 by [[Federation of Jewish Communities of Russia|the Federation of Jewish Communities of Russia]].
Kuznetsov is a semi-regular contributor to American periodicals, including ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/17/opinion/sunday/a-choice-between-boredom-and-blood.html|title=A Choice Between Boredom and Blood|date=17 August 2014|work=The New York Times}}</ref> ''[[The Huffington Post]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sergey-kuznetsov/13-absolutely-terrifying-_b_5877104.html|title=13 Absolutely Terrifying Serial Killers From Fiction|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref> and others.
===Entrepreneur=== In 2004, Kuznetsov founded a digital marketing agency called SKCG <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skcg.fr |title=SKCG |website=Skcg.fr |date= |accessdate=2016-03-04}}</ref> (an [[acronym]] for Sergey Kuznetsov Content Group), aimed at developing and supporting social media projects. The company has offices in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]] as well as [[Paris]], [[France]] and in the [[United States]]; international clients include [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Audi]], [[Nokia]], [[Estée Lauder Companies|Estée Lauder]], [[Anadolu Efes|Efes]], [[Jeep]], [[Robert Bosch GmbH|Bosch]] and other major corporations.
In 2014, Kuznetsov and his wife Ekaterina founded Marabou Science Camp,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marabou.club/about.php |title=Educational Project Marabou |website=Marabou.club |date= |accessdate=2016-03-04}}</ref> an educational project for Russian children in Europe. In 2016 they launched a Science & Vacation Program<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scienceandvacation.com |title=Science & Vacation |website=Scienceandvacation.com |date= |accessdate=2016-03-04}}</ref> aimed at explaining science to an adult audience. [[Financial Times]] called it "a company that specialises in luxury learning with a scientific bent".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://howtospendit.ft.com/articles/114333-discover-the-secret-of-scent-with-luca-turin |title=Discover the secret of scent with Luca Turin |website=Financial Times, 5 Oct 2016 }}</ref> One of S&V's first events was dedicated to neurophysics of scents. The lectures are legendary perfume critic [[Luca Turin]] and parfum blogger [[Victoria Frolova]].
== Personal life == Kuznetsov married Inna Kuznetsova in 1987. The couple divorced in 1993. In 1995, he married psychologist Ekaterina Kadieva. He has three children: Ekaterina (born in 1987), Anna (born in 1996) and Daniel (born in 2001).
He has lived in Paris since 2013.
== Recognition == In 2001, he received a [[John S. Knight Journalism Fellowships at Stanford|Knight Fellowship]] from [[Stanford University]] and moved to U.S. state of [[California]] for a year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.stanford.edu/pr/01/knightintl.html|title=International Knight Fellows named: 5/01|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.skuzn.ru/}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Louis Richard Sosthenes Behn | image = Sosthenes Behn.jpg | caption = | birth_date = January 30, 1884 | birth_place = [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. Thomas]], [[Danish West Indies]] (now [[U.S. Virgin Islands]]) | death_date = {{death date and age|1957|06|6|1884|01|30}} | death_place = New York | occupation = Co-founder of the [[Puerto Rico Telephone Company]] and [[ITT Corporation]] | salary = | networth = | spouse = Margaret Behn | children = Edward John Behn, Margaret Cecilia Ertman, William Charles Behn | parents = Wilhelm Behn, Louisa Behn | signature = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Sosthenes Behn''' (January 30, 1884 – June 6, 1957) was an American businessman widely known for founding [[ITT Corporation|ITT]]. He held the rank of lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Army.
==Biography== ===Early years=== Sosthenes Behn was born in the island of [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. Thomas]], then part of the [[Danish West Indies]]. His ancestry was [[Danes|Danish]] on his paternal side, and [[French people|French]] on his maternal side.
Behn served in the [[United States Army]] and was commissioned a Captain, Signal Corps, on June 19, 1917. He later achieved the rank of Lieutenant Colonel, having served with distinction during World War I. Behn served with the American Expeditionary Force (AEF) in France until February 1919. He was given command of the 232nd Field Signal Battalion, [[Château-Thierry]], [[Saint-Mihiel]], Argonne. In recognition of his meritorious service during the war he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Medal (U.S. Army)|Distinguished Service Medal]] (DSM).
===Puerto Rico Telephone Company and ITT=== After his return from military service, Colonel Behn co-founded the [[Puerto Rico Telephone Company]] which eventually spawned ITT<ref>Morales Cortés, Ramón. [http://www.vii.org/papers/puer.htm Telecommunications in Puerto Rico] (paper). New York, USA: ''Virtual Institute of Information''.</ref> Under his direction ITT was granted the [[monopoly]] of telephone service in [[Spain]] ([[Telefónica|Compañía Telefónica Nacional de España]]) in 1924,<ref>García-Algarra, Javier: [https://www.scribd.com/doc/53101811/The-American-Influence-in-Telefonica%E2%80%99s-Public-Relations-Strategyduring-the-20%E2%80%99s-and-30%E2%80%99s "The American influence in Telefónica's public relations strategy during the 20s and 30s"], IEEE HISTELCON 2010</ref> and purchased the international division of [[Western Electric]].
According to Anthony Sampson's book ''[[The Sovereign State of ITT]]'', one of the first American businessmen Hitler received after taking power in 1933 was Sosthenes Behn, then the CEO of ITT, and his German representative, Henry Mann. [[Antony C. Sutton]], in his book ''Wall Street and the Rise of Hitler'', makes the claim that ITT subsidiaries made cash payments to [[Schutzstaffel|SS]] leader [[Heinrich Himmler]].
ITT, through its subsidiary [[C. Lorenz AG]] of [[Berlin]], owned 25% of [[Focke-Wulf]], the German aircraft manufacturer, builder of some of the most successful [[Luftwaffe#Interwar period|Luftwaffe]] [[fighter aircraft]]. In addition, Sutton’s book uncovers that ITT owned Dr. Erich F. Huth GmbH (Signalbau Huth, Berlin), which made [[radio]] and [[radar]] parts that were used in equipment going to the [[Wehrmacht]].
Behn, along with his brother, [[Hernan Behn|Hernan]], built the ''Two Brothers Bridge'' —''Puente Dos Hermanos'' in [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]]— in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. The bridge links the districts of [[Condado, Puerto Rico|Condado]] and [[Old San Juan, Puerto Rico|Old San Juan]].
Colonel Behn and [[Ludwig Roselius]], founder of the company [[KAFFEE HAG]], owned 74% of German aircraft manufacturer Focke-Wulf after the company reconstitution in 1936. [[Barbara Goette]] referred to Colonel Behn as a huge global player.<ref>Leidig, Ludwig. Bombshell sbpra, 2013, {{ISBN|978-1-62516-346-2}}</ref> Sosthenes Behn met with Hitler on 3/8/1933 and in 1936 there was a high-level meeting in Berlin where it was proposed that Behn through ITT gain 50% of [[Focke-Wulf]] and oust [[Café HAG]] completely, but after Barbara Goette intervened with Hitler, Ludwig Roselius' life was spared and he became majority shareholder in Focke-Wulf with 46% and a massive capital injection occurred.<ref>The Office of Military Government US Zone in Post-War Germany 1946-1949, declassified per Executive Order 12958, Section 3.5 NND Project Number: NND 775057 by: NND Date: 1977.</ref>
During the war, all of ITT's German holdings were put under Nazi control. These included a minority share in airplane manufacturer Focke-Wulf, which ITT had acquired through its contacts with German financier [[Kurt Baron von Schröder]]. After the end of the war, the US authorities returned these assets to their rightful US owner.
Behn appointed [[Gerhard Westrick]] to the board of Focke-Wulf after the reconstitution in 1936. He was ITT's corporation chairman in Germany. After Pearl Harbour, at meetings with Baron Kurt von Schröder and Behn in Switzerland, Westrick nervously admitted he had run into a problem. Wilhelm Ohnesorge, the elderly minister in charge of post offices, who was one of the first fifty Nazi party members, was strongly opposed to ITT's German companies continuing to function under New York management in time of war. Behn told Westrick to use Schröder and the protection of the Gestapo against Ohnesorge. In return, Behn guaranteed that ITT would substantially increase its payments to the Gestapo through the Circle of Friends. A special board of trustees was set up by the Nazis to cooperate with Behn and his thirty thousand staff in Occupied Europe. Ohnesorge savagely fought these arrangements and tried to obtain the support of Himmler. However, Schröder had Himmler's ear, and so, of course did his close friend and associate Walter Schellenberg. Ohnesorge appealed directly to Hitler and condemned Westrick as an American sympathiser. However, Hitler realized the importance of ITT to the German economy and proved supportive of Behn.
In 1943, ITT became majority shareholder of Focke-Wulf Flugzeugbau GmbH with 29% due to Ludwig Roselius' Kaffee HAG share falling to 27% after he died on May 15.<ref>Dieter Pfliegensdörfer; Volker Bergmann; Willi Elmers; Manfred Fittkau; Michael Jung; Michael Wolf; Wolfgang Günther. Wellblech & Windkanal. Arbeit und Geschäfte im Bremer Flugzeugbau von den Anfängen 1909 bis heute. Steintor, 1989, {{ISBN|3926028513}}</ref>
===Death=== Behn died on 6 June 1957.

#REDIRECT [[Winnersh Triangle railway station]]
[[Category:High-technology business districts in the United Kingdom]]

'''''Wireless Valley''''' is a term that was coined by Professor [[Theodore Rappaport|Ted Rappaport]] in 1990 when he was a faculty member at [[Virginia Tech]], and was used to describe the [[Roanoke, Virginia|Roanoke]]/[[Blacksburg, Virginia]] region and the potential of research to create spin-out companies. In 1990 he and his students founded [[TSR Technologies]], a company that made software-defined cellular and paging intercept and drive test equipment that was sold to Allen Telecom in 1993, and in 1995 Wireless Valley Communications, a company that pioneered the creation of computer-aided [[wireless network]] prediction and management software that was sold to [[Motorola]] in late 2005. This term was later used as nickname to describe several regional clusters of companies in the [[information technology]] sector, in analogy to [[California|California's]] [[Silicon Valley]]:
* One such cluster is located in northern [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]].{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} This also included a number of companies that saw themselves as belonging to the new information based [[Economics|economy]]. [[Ericsson]], the [[telecommunications]] supplier, has one of its main design centers in the Stockholm suburb of [[Kista]]. * [[Finland]] also has a high-tech area in [[Espoo]], sometimes called "Wireless Valley", based on [[Nokia]] and [[Nokia Siemens Networks]].{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} There is a secondary hub located in [[Oulu]] which is the base for other wireless specialist companies too. * A third such cluster consists of the telecommunications formed in [[San Diego]],<ref>Markoff, John, “‘Wireless Valley’ Growing in San Diego Area,” New York Times, March 24. 1997, URL: https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990DE4D7133BF937A15750C0A961958260</ref> based on [[Qualcomm]] * A new high-tech program has been initialed in Nanjing, China, called 'China Wireless valley'.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} It is based on two national key laboratories of Southeast University.
